Shiftry.overview: Shiftry possesses several unique qualities that make it a decent, if niche, Defog user. Its typing and Synthesis allow it to reliably handle offensive threats like Jellicent, Trevenant, and Coil Sandaconda. These traits also let Shiftry easily threaten common entry hazard setters like Gigalith and Sandslash. Shiftry is also good at pressuring foes like Charizard and Doublade, which pester other entry hazard removers, because of its decent offenses and powerful STAB Knock Off. However, Shiftry's defensive typing leaves it vulnerable to many common threats, such as Ribombee and Archeops. Shiftry is also 4x weak to U-turn, which means it usually must cede momentum to users like Togedemaru and does not reliably check Wishiwashi. To make matters worse, Shiftry sits at an awkward Speed tier, with prevalent threats such as Gallade outrunning it and pressuring it out as a result. Finally, though Shiftry tends to be less passive than other entry hazard removers like Eldegoss and Whimsicott, they are more consistent due to their better defensive profiles and utility movepools.

Defog.description: By running a defensive set, Shiftry can check foes like Gigalith and offensive Sandslash while comfortably supporting its team throughout the game. Leaf Storm is Shiftry's strongest viable STAB move and doesn't become weaker if Shiftry gets burned. 96 Speed EVs let Shiftry outspeed Timid Jellicent. Pickpocket punishes foes like Audino for removing Shiftry's Heavy-Duty Boots by stealing a foes' item. Clerics such as Ribombee can keep Shiftry healthy in case it gets statused, which is not unlikely given it likes to switch in on defensive Water- and Ground-types. Ribombee also checks Fighting-types like Gallade and appreciates Shiftry for punishing switch-ins like Charizard with Knock Off. Shiftry should be paired with Pokemon that can exploit the Steel- and Poison-types that it tends to draw in. Doublade and Galarian Articuno are offensive Pokemon that fulfill this role and benefit from Shiftry removing entry hazards for them. Walls like Sandaconda and Wishiwashi also serve this purpose on top of better handling Gigalith. Sandaconda can also run Rocky Helmet to punish the use of U-turn, with Shiftry's typing making it easier to bait the move out.

Gallade.overview: Gallade is a devastatingly powerful wallbreaker thanks to its strong STAB combination, excellent Attack stat, and solid coverage moves, which hit common physical walls such as Sandaconda and Doublade for super effective damage. With access to Shadow Sneak, it can pick off faster threats like Galarian Articuno and Whimsicott. Its STAB Close Combat is naturally strong in a tier with Rock- and Steel-types like Regirock and Togedemaru everywhere, and its Psychic-type STAB moves take on Fighting-resistant Pokemon like Comfey and Garbodor pretty well. With access to Swords Dance, Gallade can become even more powerful at the cost of losing coverage options. However, Gallade's Speed, while useful for outspeeding other slow wallbreakers like Centiskorch and Perrserker, is overall lackluster, and it relies heavily on ensuring faster foes like Ribombee and Sneasel are within Shadow Sneak range if it cannot survive a hit from them. Gallade's special bulk is decent, but its physical bulk is very subpar, which, combined with its few resistances and weaknesses to popular Fairy-, Flying-, and Ghost-type moves, leaves Gallade with little defensive utility. Finally, Gallade lacks recovery, and thus it gets quickly worn down by residual damage from entry hazards, Rocky Helmet, and stray hits.

All-out Attacker.description: Psycho Cut allows Gallade to avoid activating Rocky Helmet and Aftermath, which gives Gallade more opportunities to wallbreak. Psycho Cut is fully accurate and doesn't make contact, but Zen Headbutt has more power and can help Gallade get past answers like Aromatisse with brute force. Thunder Punch and Leaf Blade deny switch-ins such as defensive Charizard and Sandaconda. Knock Off hits bulky Psychic-types like Uxie and cripples other switch-ins like Jellicent. Muscle Band ensures 2HKOs on Pokemon like Quagsire and Hattrem with Close Combat and Knock Off, respectively. Assault Vest grants Gallade more defensive utility and allows it to survive one hit from super effective special attackers like Ribombee and Charizard, but it sacrifices power. Heavy-Duty Boots is an option to avoid entry hazard damage, which can quickly wear Gallade down; however, Muscle Band is heavily recommended due to granting better odds for OHKOs and 2HKOs. Justified punishes weak Knock Offs from Pokemon like Audino. Gallade appreciates the support of pivots like Ninjask and Wishwashi; the former can threaten Gallade's offensive checks like Galarian Articuno and baits in Pokemon like Gigalith and Togedemaru for Gallade to threaten, while the latter can switch into Pokemon like Charizard that force Gallade out and provide a free switch via its slow U-turn. Entry hazards support from Pokemon like Gigalith and Ferroseed helps wear down Gallade's answers like Alcremie and Comfey, especially if Gallade removes their Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off.

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance turns Gallade into an even more powerful wallbreaker, with +2 STAB moves OHKOing Pokemon like Sandaconda and Regirock after minimal chip damage. Psycho Cut helps Gallade avoid activating Rocky Helmet and Iron Barbs, while Zen Headbutt is stronger but less consistent. Shadow Sneak is recommended to pick off faster foes like Ribombee at +2, but Knock Off can always be used to wear down switch-ins like Jellicent to sweep more easily later. Life Orb ensures the 2HKO with Close Combat on Quagsire, which can otherwise take a +2 hit due to Unaware, and provides more general power. Lum Berry is useful for avoiding status and allows Gallade to set up on Pokemon like Jellicent, Weezing, and Hattrem. A Jolly nature lets Gallade outspeed as many foes as possible, such as Modest Magmortar, and Speed tie with Timid Mesprit; an Adamant nature is unnecessary due to the sheer power behind a +2 Life Orb Gallade. This set fits mainly on more offensive teams due to its volatile nature, and it appreciates fast pivots like Ninjask and Archeops; in turn, they enjoy Gallade scaring out Togedemaru and Regirock, respectively. Without Shadow Sneak, Gallade is helpless against revenge killers like Gourgeist-S and Whimsicott, so Pokemon that can take advantage of them like Charizard and Choice Scarf Togedemaru are heavily appreciated.

Charizard.overview: Charizard's overall solid stats, great typing, and splendid movepool allow it to perform multiple roles effectively, such as special wallbreaker and physical sweeper. Its typing and decent bulk also give it a fair amount of defensive utility, allowing it to check threats like Ribombee. However, Charizard struggles to get past many metagame staples like Gigalith, particularly if it lacks Toxic, while its Speed tier leaves it unable to check threats like Sneasel.

Special Attacker.description: Charizard makes for a great wallbreaker and offensive check to Pokemon like Ribombee, Gourgeist-S, and Gallade. Toxic cripples switch-ins such as Lanturn and Gigalith; it also allows Charizard to pressure Jellicent and Aromatisse more effectively. Defog allows Charizard to clear all entry hazards as it forces out entry hazard setters like Weezing. Fighting-types like Gallade and Sawk appreciate Charizard pressuring their switch-ins such as Ribombee. In exchange, they can take on Charizard's answers like Gigalith and Lanturn. Pokemon like Sandaconda and Jellicent make for good partners thanks to their ability to take on attackers that force Charizard out like Lycanroc and Basculin, respectively. On sun teams, Solar Power is an option, as it makes Charizard significantly harder to switch into. On such teams, it should forego Hurricane for Solar Beam and run Weather Ball in the fourth moveslot, and Choice Specs is an option over Heavy-Duty Boots. Charizard should also be paired with other Pokemon that take advantage of sun such as Shiftry.

Defensive.description: Thanks to its great utility options and defensive profile, Charizard can offer teams valuable support while also checking prominent threats such as Ribombee and Choice Specs Whimsicott. With Toxic, it can more easily wear down common switch-ins in Gigalith, Regirock, and Lanturn. Mystical Fire can be used as a STAB option over Flamethrower to help Charizard take on Stored Power users, notably Mesprit, Uxie, and Claydol. The move also allows Charizard to beat Scald Jellicent alongside Toxic. Good teammates for Charizard would be Pokemon such as Perrserker and Trevenant, as they help further break down Rock- and Water-types such as Regirock and Jellicent, respectively. Pokemon like Sandaconda and Weezing also pair well with Charizard, setting entry hazards to help weaken its checks and absorbing Knock Off for it. Finally, teammates such as Quiver Dance Ribombee and Nasty Plot Mesprit appreciate Charizard crippling Gigalith with Toxic, as they have a hard time breaking through it even after a boost.

Dragon Dance.description: Charizard's impressive Speed and coverage allows it to outspeed common Choice Scarf users like Togedemaru and Mesprit as well as threaten its would-be switch-ins such as Gigalith after a Dragon Dance. Roost allows Charizard to switch into threats like Ribombee and Whimsicott as well as set up more easily, while Thunder Punch is Charizard's best option to hit Jellicent, having a solid chance of 2HKOing it; it also hits Archeops and opposing Charizard. Charizard's middling Attack means it can't sweep unless the opposing team is very weakened; this makes wallbreakers like Vikavolt and Trevenant very appreciated. They can both take on defensive behemoths such as Jellicent and Regirock that Charizard struggles against. Choice Scarf Togedemaru can check Lycanroc; similarly, Froslass can wear down its shared checks with Charizard, like Gigalith, particularly with Spikes.

Sandslash.overview: With access to Sand Rush, decent stats and typing, and an expansive movepool, Sandslash is a versatile offensive and defensive presence and a defining member of PU sand teams. Swords Dance Sandslash is one of the most dangerous sweepers in the tier. Under the effect of sand, it outspeeds almost the entire unboosted metagame and even some Choice Scarf users such as Gallade. Its typing and decent natural physical bulk give it ample setup opportunities against the common Rock- and Steel-types such as Gigalith and Togedemaru. Once boosted by Swords Dance, it has very few reliable defensive answers, and with access to useful coverage moves in Rock Slide, Leech Life, Knock Off, and Poison Jab, it can choose to narrow down its checks and counters even further. With its utility options in Rapid Spin, Spikes, and Knock Off, Sandslash also carves itself a niche as a versatile spinner that can compress several roles in one slot. Due to it's lack of reliable recovery along with its average stats, it can get worn down rather quickly, and can't be relied upon to repeatedly take on strong attackers like Perrserker. Furthermore, its poor special bulk and low Speed outside of sand leave it vulnerable to special attackers like Magneton, and common utility Pokemon like Wishiwashi, Eldegoss, and Levitate Weezing can exploit its overall passivity to gain momentum via U-turn, and either remove or set up entry hazards of their own.

Offensive Swords Dance.description:
Most Rock-weak Ground-resistant Pokemon like Ribombee, Charizard, and Archeops are already OHKOed by Rock Slide; as such, it is preferred over the stronger, but less accurate Stone Edge. Stone Edge can still be used to deal more damage to neutral targets when not running Leech Life or Poison Jab. After using Swords Dance, Leech Life in conjunction with Life Orb allows Sandslash to OHKO Eldegoss. It also allows Sandslash to threaten Tangela. With Knock Off, Sandslash can OHKO Trevenant and weaken Pokémon that wall it, namely Levitate Weezing, Quagsire, and Tangela. Sandslash can perform as an effective offensive spinner. Rapid Spin is also useful for boosting its Speed outside of sand. Instead of Leech Life, Poison Jab can be used to OHKO defensive Whimsicott. Life Orb is the most powerful choice of an item for a dedicated sweeper set, notably allowing Sandslash to OHKO Eldegoss. Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots can be used to improve Sandslash's longevity instead, particularly if an utility move is chosen as the last moveslot. A Jolly Nature can be considered to outspeed Choice Scarf Togedemaru and a few other uncommon Choice Scarf users like Gourgeist-S in sand, and Modest Magneton when unboosted, but this is typically not worth the drop in power.

Swords Dance Sandslash should be ran with Gigalith, as it is the only viable sand setter in the tier. Spikes or Toxic Spikes support from the likes of Ferroseed, Weezing, or Qwilfish is appreciated to help Sandslash break through physically defensive walls like Sandaconda, Jellicent, and Wishiwashi. Ribombee and Whimsicott are useful utility Pokemon that can use U-turn to bring Sandslash safely into their typical Steel- and Rock-type switch-ins, like Togedemaru, Aggron, and Gigalith. Galarian Articuno and Vikavolt can switch in on Grass-types that check Sandslash and fire off powerful attacks or pivot with U-turn and Volt Switch, respectively. Charizard is a great Gigalith magnet that also counters most Grass-types and wears down Wishiwashi and Jellicent with Toxic. Wallbreakers like Gallade can weaken walls like Tangela, while Sandslash itself can benefit sweepers such as Doublade, dealing heavy damage to their shared checks.

Utility.description:
Knock Off makes typical Sandslash switch-ins like Eldegoss and Wishiwashi more susceptible to residual damage, including Sandslash's own Spikes, by removing their Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers and discouraging spinblockers like Trevenant from switching in. Spikes are chosen to wear down grounded targets, forming an entry hazard-stacking core with Gigalith. If you choose to not use Gigalith, Stealth Rock is a viable option. Leftovers give Sandslash a bit of passive recovery, improving its longevity. Heavy-Duty Boots is an alternative that protects Sandslash from entry hazards, particularly Toxic Spikes. Sandslash's EV spread is quite flexible and it can easily run some Speed investment to outpace certain threats according to its team's needs. One of the possibilities is a spread of 248 HP / 124 Def / 136 Spe to outpace Adamant Perrserker outside of sand, while outspeeding Jolteon in sand.

Although this set does not necessarily require sand in order to function, Gigalith is still recommended. With a Sand Rush boost, Sandslash is far less passive, and it can be situationally used to revenge kill Pokemon like Magmortar. Gigalith can also take care of most special attackers, including Charizard and Ribombee. Pokemon that can switch into bulky Grass- and Water-types are necessary, as these will often come in on Sandslash to remove its Spikes, block Rapid Spin, or gain momentum. Weezing is a solid switch-in to Grass-types and can help wear down the opposition with Toxic Spikes. Eldegoss can deal with most Water-types and provide cleric support. Running Eldegoss along with Sandslash also allows you to free up a moveslot that is typically occupied by Rapid Spin on either of the two Pokemon. Wallbreakers like Magneton and Galarian Articuno can take advantage of the likes of Eldegoss and Weezing. Doublade has good typing synergy with both Sandslash and Gigalith, can effectively spinblock and, as a late-game sweeper, benefits from Spikes wearing down its checks.

Clefairy.overview: Clefairy fulfills a niche as one of the few viable pure Fairy-types within the tier, lacking the weaknesses that Ribombee has to Fire and Flying while keeping the defensive utility of a Fairy-type. Its main niches over other Fairy-types like Aromatisse are its access to Knock Off, which makes common Fairy-type switch-ins like Charizard and Centiskorch bad options, and Magic Guard, which means it doesn't care about chip damage. With a wide support movepool featuring moves like Stealth Rock and Encore, along with reliable recovery, it can compress roles on certain teams effectively. However, despite these qualities, Clefairy is heavily reliant on its item to keep its bulk. It also suffers from competition with other pure Fairy-types like Aromatisse and Comfey; the former has more physical bulk and is less hindered by its item being removed, while the latter has Taunt and priority in Triage Draining Kiss. Finally, without Encore, Clefairy is liable to be taken advantage of by setup sweepers like Uxie and Doublade.

Defensive.description: Moonblast lets Clefairy hit foes like Thievul and Absol, while Seismic Toss deals consistent damage to targets with high Special Defense like Gigalith and Steel-types like Aggron. Knock Off cripples Pokemon heavily reliant on their items like Doublade and Charizard. Encore prevents setup and can deter recovery moves from being used. Thunder Wave cripples faster foes like Galarian Articuno and Jellicent. Running 10 Speed IVs is an option to always avoid the 2HKO from Gyro Ball Ferroseed; however, this means that Clefairy underspeeds important Pokemon like Gigalith and Quagsire. Clefairy struggles against Poison- and Steel-types like Weezing and Ferroseed, so switch-ins to them like Wishiwashi and Charizard are heavily appreciated. Wishiwashi sponges Knock Off from Gallade and Sandslash for Clefairy, while in return, Clefairy is able to take on its checks like Lanturn; as for Charizard, Clefairy switches into Rock-types like Gigalith and Regirock for it.

Dugtrio-Alola.overview: Alolan Dugtrio's high Speed, high Attack, and Sand Force ability make it a niche option on offensive sand teams. Given a free turn, Alolan Dugtrio massively threatens many tier staples such as Gigalith, Charizard, and Ribombee. However, Alolan Dugtrio's poor bulk limits its opportunities to switch into these targets, and its power, while great, may occasionally come up short against very bulky targets such as Doublade. Additionally, Alolan Dugtrio's very poor bulk makes it susceptible to priority revenge killers such as Thwackey as well as faster threats such as Cinccino and Choice Scarf Gallade.

Sand Wallbreaker.description: Earthquake is Alolan Dugtrio's strongest move and boasts immense power under sand, OHKOing offensive Jellicent and having a good chance to 2HKO Quagsire after Stealth Rock. Iron Head is a secondary STAB move that slams many Pokemon resistant or immune to Ground, such as Eldegoss and the aforementioned Ribombee. Sucker Punch is a good option to pick off faster Pokemon that would otherwise revenge kill Alolan Dugtrio, such as Cinccino and Lycanroc. Memento can be used to help a teammate such as Sandslash set up and potentially sweep. Rock Slide hits Flying-types such as Charizard and Levitate users such as Vikavolt. Gigalith is a mandatory partner for Alolan Dugtrio because it provides sand as well as Stealth Rock to help chip down some of Alolan Dugtrio's checks, such as Cinccino, into range for its attacks. Other Pokemon that pair well with it include Sand Rush sweepers such as Sandslash, as well as Doublade, since it can switch into physical attackers that may try to revenge kill Alolan Dugtrio.

Persian-Alola.overview: While Alolan Persian has various desirable qualities between a diverse movepool, a great ability in Fur Coat, and an amazing Speed stat, they ultimately aren't enough to keep it from being a niche option. A lack of reliable recovery makes Alolan Persian very easy to wear down throughout the match via entry hazards and sand damage, limiting how many times it can switch into attacks or pivot in and out. The metagame's abundance of Fairy-types can prove difficult for Alolan Persian, with Ribombee and Whimsicott even outspeeding it naturally. Offensively, with Alolan Persian's mediocre offensive stats and lack of a secondary typing, it is notably outclassed by Sneasel, which shares its base 115 Speed and Dark typing. However, Alolan Persian's high Speed and great utility moves stop it from being completely deadweight, specifically when paired with Choice Scarf, which allows it to cripple bulky threats with Switcheroo and serve as an extremely fast pivot. While Choice Scarf may seem redundant with Alolan Persian's high Speed, it allows Alolan Persian to outspeed even more Pokemon like Sand Rush Sandslash, +1 Flame Charge Silvally-Fairy, and non-Choice Scarf Whimsicott.

Choice Scarf.description: When paired with Choice Scarf, Switcheroo can cripple walls like Quagsire and Gigalith. With 232 Speed EVs and a Jolly nature, Alolan Persian outspeeds Lycanroc and Archeops even after losing its Choice Scarf. Parting Shot or U-turn are vital to gain and maintain momentum: Parting Shot weakens the foe at risk of triggering Galarian Articuno's Competitive, while U-turn provides negligible chip damage but risks self-damage from Rocky Helmet and Iron Barbs. STAB Knock Off alongside Switcheroo gives Alolan Persian great item control, although remember that Knock Off would remove the foe's Choice Scarf after Switcheroo. Gunk Shot is Alolan Persian's best coverage option, hitting Fairy-types like Ribombee and Whimsicott, although be aware that Ribombee can also run Choice Scarf and outspeed Alolan Persian. Alternatively, Foul Play helps make up for Alolan Persian's low Attack stat, Toxic further cripples defensive threats, and Taunt stops moves like Gigalith's Stealth Rock or Tangela's Sleep Powder. Alolan Persian is best as a lead, using Switcheroo against common leads like Gigalith and Ferroseed or pivoting out to gain early momentum. Alolan Persian can continue to pivot in and out throughout the match and serve as speed control if still holding the Choice Scarf. As a pivot, Alolan Persian pairs well with other pivots like Wishiwashi and Vikavolt to maintain momentum, entry hazard removers like Silvally-Steel and Charizard to switch in more, and hazard setters like Mesprit and Sandslash to further punish the opponent's switches. Lastly, Alolan Persian's Switcheroo can give Pokemon like Ribombee and Silvally-Ghost free turns to set up, potentially locking foes into utility moves like Stealth Rock or resisted attacks like Drain Punch.

Poliwrath.overview: Thanks to its interesting assortment of attributes, Poliwrath has a unique place in PU and can provide teams with incredibly useful role compression. On top of naturally taking on Sneasel and Aggron due to its typing and bulk, Poliwrath also checks opposing Water-types like Wishiwashi thanks to Water Absorb, which distinguishes it from Quagsire. Poliwrath's movepool is also solid, containing good offensive and defensive tools that let it function as either a powerful wallbreaker or sturdy phazer. Beyond this, Poliwrath can potentially run other sets that make different use of its good traits, such as Choice Scarf, which mitigates its mediocre Speed tier. Despite being proficient in various areas, however, Poliwrath is not a master in any one of them. Poliwrath's meager offensive stats mean its damage output can be lackluster at times, which tends to make its defensive set even more passive. Poliwrath checks a lot of the tier, but common Pokemon like Galarian Articuno, Ribombee, and Charizard similarly threaten it. Finally, Poliwrath faces serious competition in its roles from more prevalent Pokemon. In terms of other wallbreakers, Basculin is faster and has access to priority and Flip Turn, while Jellicent can be harder to answer immediately due to Water Spout. As for defensive pivots, Lanturn and Wishiwashi more comfortably deal with Charizard and generate momentum for teams.

Choice Band.description: Common Water-resistant foes like Ferroseed find switching into Poliwrath difficult thanks to its powerful Close Combat. Darkest Lariat threatens Ghost-types like Jellicent, which otherwise walls Poliwrath, and Cofagrigus, which despises that the move also ignores Defense boosts. Earthquake deals more damage to Lanturn than Close Combat and can 2HKO Doublade from full after Stealth Rock. Poison Jab is another option that hits Fairy-types like Silvally-Fairy and Aromatisse harder than any other move Poliwrath viably runs. Fire-types such as Charizard and Centiskorch are good offensive checks to Grass- and Fairy-types and can support Poliwrath by wearing down its checks with either status or coverage and, in Charizard's case, removing entry hazards. In return, Poliwrath protects them against Water-type attacks and pressures switch-ins to them like Audino and Aggron. Galarian Articuno can similarly check Grass-types on top of bringing Poliwrath in safely with U-turn punishing its switch-ins with Future Sight. In return, Poliwrath pressures special walls like Gigalith and Audino and offensively checks Pokemon like Sneasel and Glastrier.

Defensive.description: Circle Throw prevents setup sweepers like Uxie and Quagsire from switching in on and exploiting Poliwrath. Rest lets Poliwrath remain healthy so that it can switch into threats like Absol with more ease throughout the game, and Sleep Talk limits its passivity while it's sleeping. 96 Speed EVs allow Poliwrath to outspeed Adamant Aggron and Speed tie with Sandaconda. Spikes and Toxic Spikes become especially difficult to play around due to how disruptive Poliwrath can be, with Ferroseed and Weezing being premier users of these moves, respectively. The former offers Poliwrath safety against opposing Water-types like Lanturn and Wishiwashi, the latter keeps Grass-types like Whimsicott at bay, and both can check Fairy-types like Ribombee. As for Stealth Rock users, Gigalith is a notable example, since it also provides sand to further wear foes down and takes on Pokemon such as Charizard and Vikavolt. These entry hazard setters appreciate Poliwrath absorbing Knock Off and punishing threats like Sneasel looking to exploit them. Galarian Articuno can be devastating alongside Poliwrath thanks to Circle Throw, which may force a critical member of the opposing team to take heavy damage from or be KOed by Future Sight. In return, Poliwrath annoys Pokemon such as Aggron and Sneasel that can switch into or revenge kill Galarian Articuno. Ghost-types such as Trevenant and Silvally-Ghost are really good at exploiting Poliwrath, which makes having teammates like Tangela that can deal with them important. Tangela also commonly runs Knock Off, which makes spreading residual damage easier for Poliwrath.

Magneton.overview: Because of its good offensive typing, high Special Attack, and strong STAB options, Magneton can serve as a threatening wallbreaker that pressures defensive staples like Eldegoss and Gigalith. Analytic compensates for Magneton's middling Speed tier while also making it more difficult to switch into. Magneton can effectively take advantage of this thanks to its access to Volt Switch, putting opponents on the back foot while also generating momentum for its teammates. However, Pokemon such as Lanturn, Lightning Rod Togedemaru, and Galarian Stunfisk makes walling Magneton easier for a lot of teams. Magneton's average Speed also leaves it outsped by common offensive threats like Gallade and Charizard. Finally, due to its poor bulk, Magneton often struggles to safely switch in even on resisted hits and can't make full use of the defensive benefits that come with its Steel typing.

Choice Specs.description: Tri Attack provides Magneton with neutral coverage for Lanturn and Vikavolt while still hitting Ground-types like Quagsire. Teleport is another option that lets Magneton pivot out against Electric-immune Pokemon like Lightning Rod Togedemaru. Alternatively, Steel Beam can potentially OHKO even Audino on the switch, which Flash Cannon cannot achieve. Other pivots such as Archeops pair well with Magneton, since they create a momentum core and help to exert increased pressure on opposing teams. These examples also threaten nuisances like Galarian Stunfisk and offer Knock Off support, while Magneton threatens physically bulky Pokemon like Weezing. Walls like Aromatisse, Weezing, and Gigalith serve as a safety net against faster Fire-types like Charizard and Magmortar that force Magneton out. Pokemon like Sandaconda and Eldegoss provide Magneton with speed control in Glare and Stun Spore, respectively, which gives it more opportunities to wallbreak by making it harder to immediately threaten out. These examples falter against Pokemon such as Trevenant, Whimsicott, and Silvally-Steel, all of which Magneton can potentially exploit.

Haunter.overview: Haunter finds a niche as a wallbreaker that opens holes for its teammates with a unique STAB combination that benefits from the tier's lack of common resistances to Ghost-types. Unlike other Ghost-type wallbreakers such as Trevenant and Silvally-Ghost, Shadow Ball allows Haunter to bypass pseudo-Ghost-type checks like itemless Togedemaru and Weezing. This allows teammates to run item removal, which makes it more flexible than Trevenant. Furthermore, the ability to choose its item, access to a secondary STAB to break past Normal-types more easily, and consistent super effective coverage against bulky Dark-types like Alolan Persian gives Haunter a valuable niche over Silvally-Ghost. While Haunter’s secondary STAB is less spammable, the ability to beat Fairy-types like Silvally-Fairy and Clefairy is useful. A mix of good damage output, solid Speed tier, and Sludge Bomb, which poisons switch-ins, make it a unique special attacker over the likes of Vikavolt and Ribombee. Haunter outpaces several offensive threats such as Gallade, Mesprit, and Centiskorch. However, it is left lacking against faster threats such as Archeops and Charizard, both of which force Haunter out. It also has a Speed tie with offensive Silvally formes and Timid Galarian Articuno, which makes it inconsistent at threatening them. Despite three immunities and a 4x resistance to U-turn, Haunter lacks meaningful defensive utility due to its horrendous bulk and thus only takes advantage of passive Pokemon that it resists like Aromatisse. Haunter is also switched into easily by blanket special walls such as Gigalith, Lanturn, Audino, and Togedemaru.

Substitute + 3 Attacks.description: This set capitalizes on the switches Haunter forces by setting up a Substitute, which eases prediction and negates otherwise threatening priority from Pokemon like Absol, and dissuading faster Pokemon like Charizard from coming in. Will-O-Wisp allows Haunter to cripple Gigalith and other bulky walls. Energy Ball gives Haunter a stronger attack versus Rock-, Ground-, and Water-types such as Regirock, Quagsire, and Wishiwashi. Disable takes advantage of Pokemon that have only one attack that can break Haunter's Substitute such as Palossand and Flamethrower Weezing. Life Orb gives Haunter the most power while allowing it to switch moves. Choice Specs in tandem with Trick or Energy Ball instead of Substitute is an option that increases Haunter's power, notably allowing it to 2HKO Togedemaru. However, it is then more easily pressured by Pokemon that can outspeed it like Charizard and more reliant on prediction to succeed. Haunter struggles against Gigalith commonly running Rock Blast, so partners with a type advantage such as Sandaconda and Poliwrath are appreciated. Sandaconda also provides entry hazard support, while Poliwrath can bait in checks like Aromatisse and Weezing for Haunter to threaten. Other Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gallade also make solid partners, as they both lure in Ghost-types like Palossand and Jellicent that Haunter can break through. In return, they check Normal- and Dark-type threats to Haunter like Audino and Absol.

Choice Scarf.description: The advantage that Choice Scarf Haunter has over other sets is the ability to revenge kill various Choice Scarfers like Mesprit and Rotom, as well as various sweepers like Adamant Sandslash in sand. Dazzling Gleam lets Haunter revenge kill fast Dark-types such as Alolan Persian, while Energy Ball better threatens various foes such as Lanturn. Trick allows Haunter to cripple passive checks like Audino. Haunter is very frail, so it appreciates pivot support from the likes of Togedemaru and Archeops, which can bring Haunter in on their switch-ins like Weezing and Quagsire in order to wallbreak. Blanket special walls like Gigalith, Audino, and Lanturn can switch into Haunter multiple times during a match, so partners that can wear them down such as Ribombee and Charizard, are useful to Haunter.

Exeggutor.overview: Exeggutor's combination of high Special Attack, Leaf Storm, and Psychic typing make it much harder to safely switch into, unlike other Grass-types like Whimsicott and Eldegoss. However, Exeggutor's bulk, defensive typing, and Speed leave much to be desired, so it's easily offensively checked by Pokemon such as Charizard and U-turn Silvally-Steel. Furthermore, Exeggutor's lacking coverage leaves it easily walled by Pokemon such as Ferroseed and Galarian Articuno. Overall, this can leave Exeggutor difficult to justify over other superior Grass-types and Choice Specs users such as Whimsicott, Mesprit, and Jellicent.

Choice Specs.description: Psychic is preferred to Psyshock for its greater damage output, but the latter can be used instead of or alongside it to help with special walls like Audino. Giga Drain is a more accurate Grass-type attack and gives Exeggutor some longevity. The last moveslot is very flexible, with Future Sight taking advantage of Exeggutor's high Special Attack to force switches, Sleep Powder crippling potential switch-ins like Togedemaru and Teleport gaining momentum. These moves can allow teammates like Gigalith and Ribombee to set up Stealth Rock and Quiver Dance, respectively. Exeggutor also pairs well with Pokemon such as Doublade and Sandslash, as it can help weaken their checks such as Quagsire and defensive Eldegoss. Exeggutor can struggle to take a hit when switching in, so slow pivots such as Wishiwashi and Lanturn are beneficial. It is important to note that since Exeggutor is locked into an attack, it can be easily taken advantage of by Pokemon like Swords Dance Sneasel and Quiver Dance Frosmoth, especially when locking into Leaf Storm.

Hitmonlee.overview: With Hitmonlee's strong Attack and Unburden, it can function as a great Terrain sweeper. It has solid coverage and has passable bulk to set up with after using Electric or Grassy Seed. However, outside of Terrain teams, Hitmonlee is outclassed by other Fighting-types in the tier like Gallade due to Hitmonlee being reliant on Unburden to make progress. While it has the ability to set up, Hitmonlee still finds itself unable to get past Pokemon like Charizard and Aromatisse if it does not have the right coverage move.

Terrain Sweeper.description: Hitmonlee is exclusively used on Terrain teams, which, in tandem with Electric Seed or Grassy Seed, help it set up with Bulk Up more easily. Close Combat is Hitmonlee's best STAB move, as it does not run the same risk to miss as High Jump Kick does. Knock Off gives Hitmonlee coverage for Pokemon like Mesprit and Silvally-Ghost, cripples Pokemon like Weezing, and hits Flying-types if Hitmonlee is not running Stone Edge. Stone Edge allows Hitmonlee to remove Flying-types such as Charizard with ease. Alternatively, Poison Jab gives Hitmonlee coverage for Fairy-types like Aromatisse and Silvally-Fairy. Hitmonlee requires either Pincurchin or Thwackey as a partner and therefore pairs well with other Terrain sweepers like Thievul. On Electric Terrain teams, Jolteon can pressure Flying-types for Hitmonlee so it can run Poison Jab, and Nature Power Ribombee can lure Charizard if Electric Terrain is still active. For Grassy Terrain teams, Thwackey is able to wear down Pokemon like Weezing and Charizard for Hitmonlee to break through late-game.

Weezing.overview: Weezing's physical bulk, wide utility movepool, and abilities allow it to function as a great defensive pick for teams. A pure Poison typing leaves it with only two weaknesses, one of which can be negated by Levitate, and important resistances, letting it wall Pokemon that utilize Grass- and Fighting-type moves such as Gourgeist-S and Hitmonlee. A solid Special Attack stat and the threat of status make Weezing hard to switch into as well, and the ability to lay Toxic Spikes allows it to provide support for its team and wear down its checks. However, Weezing's low special bulk means even neutral strong special hits will take a big chunk out of its health. Weezing also has unreliable recovery, especially if it forgoes Black Sludge, since its only viable option is Pain Split. A weakness to Psychic also leaves it forced out by foes such as Mesprit and Gallade, and by those with Psychic-type coverage, such as Whimsicott and Ribombee, if it is chipped enough. Choosing Neutralizing Gas also means it struggles with Ground-types such as Sandslash.

Defensive Utility.description: Weezing can function as both a wall and a supporter. Will-O-Wisp cripples against Pokemon immune to poison such as Aggron and Ferroseed. Taunt can be used to shut down opposing defensive Pokemon such as Gigalith and Regirock. Flamethrower allows Weezing to threaten Steel-types and Froslass beyond a burn. Neutralizing Gas sacrifices a Ground immunity to let Weezing take advantage of Pokemon that rely heavily on their abilities, such as Audino and Gigalith, and also lets it absorb Toxic Spikes. The given EV spread allows Weezing to outspeed Pokemon like defensive Alcremie. Weezing pairs best with specially defensive Pokemon that can absorb special hits for it; these include blanket checks to special attackers, such as Gigalith and Lanturn, which enjoy Weezing soaking up Fighting- and Grass-type moves for them. Steel-types like Ferroseed and Aggron can handle special attackers like Mesprit, Ribombee, and Galarian Articuno that can overwhelm Weezing. In return, Weezing can absorb Fighting- and, if running Levitate, Ground-type moves for them.

Rhydon.overview: Rhydon is a solid Stealth Rock user thanks to its great Eviolite-boosted bulk, fearsome Attack stat, good coverage choices, and excellent offensive typing. Its STAB EdgeQuake combination is difficult to switch into, especially when combined with coverage options like Heat Crash to deter frailer Grass-types like Gourgeist-S and Whimsicott from switching in. Rhydon's bulk and defensive typing enable it to become a decent offensive switch-in to common staples like Charizard, Gigalith, and Archeops while also being capable of threatening out Defoggers like Rotom, Articuno, and Silvally-Poison. While Rhydon has a terrific offensive typing, it is weak to numerous common attacking types, causing it to falter against certain entry hazard removers like Whimsicott and Eldegoss. Rhydon's low Special Defense, Speed, and lack of reliable recovery cause it to get worn down very quickly by entry hazards and status, making it reliant on cleric support to aid its longevity.

Offensive Stealth Rock.description: Heat Crash allows Rhydon to lure in and OHKO Ferroseed and Whimsicott as well as Gourgeist-S after Stealth Rock. Rhydon can set up with Swords Dance against passive foes like Audino and Clefairy, making it even more difficult to switch into. Rhydon can also run a more specially defensive set with an EV spread of 252 HP / 16 Atk / 240 SpD to switch into Ribombee and Charizard more reliably and trade against offensive teams. However, this comes at the cost of losing a lot of its offensive presence. Rhydon enjoys Grass-types like Trevenant, Gourgeist-S, and Tangela covering against its weaknesses to Water, Ground, and Grass. In return, Rhydon can switch into Fire- and Flying-type attacks aimed at them. Ferroseed pairs particularly well with Rhydon to form an entry hazard-stacking core, wearing down each other's checks, although they must be wary of their shared weakness to Fighting. Cleric support from Audino and Aromatisse can patch up Rhydon's vulnerability to getting worn down by entry hazards and status.

Tangela.overview: Tangela's solid bulk, further bolstered by Eviolite, in combination with its great ability in Regenerator makes it a great switch-in to top physical threats like Archeops, Silvally-Fairy, and Trevenant. Tangela also has great supportive options such as Knock Off, Leech Seed, Toxic, and Sleep Powder, which makes up for its mediocre damage output. However, Tangela is held back by its poor special bulk and bad typing, as being pure Grass leaves it vulnerable to a plethora of top Pokemon like Ribombee, Vikavolt, and Charizard. Additionally, Tangela is very reliant on its item Eviolite, and a lot of Pokemon that it checks carry Knock Off, making Tangela less reliable of an answer to them. Furthermore, it dislikes getting poisoned by Toxic, making it less effective as a pivot.

Defensive.description: Knock Off is a great utility move and is able to remove items such as Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon such as Centiskorch, Charizard, and Ribombee. Leech Seed allows Tangela to cripple answers like Charizard and potentially help a teammate like Regirock, although Synthesis gives it an easier time beating Pokemon like Absol in a one-on-one, which it can't reliably do when running Leech Seed. Toxic cripples defensive Pokemon better, while Sleep Powder cripples offensive Pokemon such as Gallade and allows it to bring a wallbreaker or setup sweeper in with more ease. Rock-types such as Gigalith check Fire-types such as Magmortar and Charizard. Lanturn also checks threats like Magmortar, Charizard, and Galarian Articuno that Tangela dislikes; it can also provide Heal Bell support for Tangela. In return, Tangela checks Sandslash and Sandaconda for them and can bolster their health with Leech Seed. Since Tangela hates Poison-types like Weezing, partners like Mesprit and Vikavolt are appreciated. In return, Tangela checks Absol and Togedemaru for them. Frail wallbreakers like Magneton, Archeops, and the aforementioned Vikavolt dislike the presence of foes such as Gallade, Togedemaru, and Lycanroc, so Tangela makes for a great defensive backbone to rely on.

Ditto.overview: Ditto is a niche setup deterrent with the combination of Imposter and Choice Scarf. It removes sweepers like Ribombee and Swords Dance Sneasel and revenge kills fast foes such as Archeops and Whimsicott as well. Ditto also has a fair amount of utility against stall, being able to infinitely copy Audino and Aromatisse and use Wish to win long games. However, Ditto most often will not contribute to a team defensively due to its low HP stat, and it fails to check Substitute users like Perrserker and bulky setup sweepers like Uxie. This generally makes other revenge killers or defensive support better additions to aid against sweepers.

Imposter.description: Transform is Ditto's only move option, but it should not ever have to click it anyhow with Imposter. The given EVs and nature allow for a stronger Future Sight after copying Pokemon like Galarian Articuno. The Quiet nature and 0 Speed IVs allow Ditto to have Imposter activate last in the rare mirror matchup with more Transform PP. Ditto fits best on stall builds, as they have the defensive structure to support Ditto while appreciating its unique blanket revenge killing capabilities. Slow pivots like defensive Uxie and Togedemaru are good partners to safely allow Ditto to check foes such as Lycanroc and Silvally-Steel. Ditto cannot reliably beat common bulky setup sweepers like Coil Sandaconda, making one of Haze Quagsire or Spite Pyukumuku solid support. They also wall Ninjask, which Ditto cannot properly check because of Speed Boost. Ditto is vulnerable to all entry hazards, bar Sticky Web, so consistent hazard removers like Articuno and Charizard are essential.

Jolteon.overview: Jolteon makes good use of its high Speed stat and decent power on bulky offense teams to threaten faster offense teams. It most notably outpaces Ribombee and other Pokemon like Sneasel and Cinccino. It becomes a nightmare for hyper offensive teams that fail to fit a Ground-type, as they are just frail enough for Jolteon to pressure effectively. However, against bulkier teams, its lesser power is more noticeable, as it struggles to make much progress on its own. This lesser power on top of its frailty allows foes like Gallade to trade with it. Jolteon's coverage options are also terrible, making it easier to pivot around even without an Electric-immune Pokemon, as Jolteon struggles against Ferroseed and Eldegoss regardless.

Offensive Pivot.description: Shadow Ball hits Ground-types such as Sandslash and Rhydon, as well as other Electric-immune Pokemon like Lightning Rod Togedemaru. Hyper Voice functions as additional neutral coverage, not as spammable as Shadow Ball but doing a little more to neutral Pokemon like opposing Jolteon. With Heavy-Duty Boots, Toxic can cripple specially defensive Pokemon like Audino and Gigalith before Jolteon pivots out. Heal Bell provides more utility for teammates when Jolteon cannot make progress otherwise. Choice Specs gives Jolteon immediate power to clean up frail teams with Thunderbolt and notably OHKO Ribombee and Wishiwashi from full health. Heavy-Duty Boots lets Jolteon pivot more freely and run support moves but makes it struggle more to revenge kill foes. Jolteon can form reliable VoltTurn cores with Pokemon such as Wishiwashi and Whimsicott. These Pokemon also can deal with Ground-types like Sandaconda for Jolteon. Wallbreakers like Gallade and Sandslash can capitalize on bulky foes like Audino and Gigalith that Jolteon draws in as well. Fire-types like Centiskorch and Charizard take advantage of the Grass-types that check Jolteon, like Whimsicott. In return, Jolteon can pressure Water-types like Wishiwashi or spread Toxic poison onto foes like Gigalith.

Articuno.overview: Articuno secures itself a niche on defensive teams as a solid Defogger with unique qualities. Its great special bulk and reliable recovery let it take on Pokemon such as Ribombee, Mesprit, and Frosmoth without much issue. Pressure + Defog can threaten entry hazard users that don't threaten Articuno, such as Druddigon and Mesprit, and it is able to stall Pokemon such as Whimsicott lacking Knock Off and Palossand due to its massive special bulk. Unfortunately, Articuno's typing gives it few relevant resistances and weaknesses to common types such as Electric, Fire and Steel as well as a 4x weakness to Rock-types. This makes Articuno reliant on Heavy-Duty Boots to avoid Stealth Rock and very vulnerable to Knock Off. Articuno often requires dedicated support to succeed and only fits on specific playstyles such as stall or semi-stall.

Specially Defensive.description: Freeze-Dry hits Ground-types such as Sandaconda and Rhydon as well as Water-types such as Lanturn and Jellicent. Alternatively, U-turn generates momentum for Articuno's team but cannot directly threaten the aforementioned Ground- and Water-types. Brave Bird hits Bug-types such as Ribombee and Centiskorch and prevents them from turning Articuno into setup fodder. Heal Bell can be used for cleric and frees up a slot for the most common cleric on defensive teams, Audino. Toxic is also an option to cripple switch-ins such as Gigalith and Magmortar, but it lacks the utility of either Brave Bird or Heal Bell. The given Speed EVs let Articuno outspeed neutral-natured base 65 Speed foes such as Centiskorch and Frosmoth, while the remaining EVs go into its special bulk to better check Ribombee and Galarian Articuno. Since Articuno mainly fits on stall teams, it should be paired with Knock Off absorbers such as Sandaconda and Weezing; Sandaconda also absorbs status, while Weezing can burn physical attackers. In return, it provides valuable Defog support and checks Frosmoth and Centiskorch, which have good matchups against defensive teams. Other entry hazard removers such as Claydol and Eldegoss can free up a moveslot for Articuno and allow it to run another utility move while also threatening entry hazard setters such as Reigrock and Gigalith. Articuno's common weaknesses can be negated by partners such as Palossand and Quagsire. Both absorb Electric- and Rock-type moves, with Palossand also providing Stealth Rock support and Quagsire taking on Fire- and Steel-type moves for Articuno.

Articuno-Galar.overview: Galarian Articuno is one of PU's best and most dangerous special attackers thanks to its high Special Attack and great offensive typing. Part of what makes Galarian Articuno so threatening is Future Sight, which can severely limit its counterplay. Furthermore, Galarian Articuno is somewhat versatile, capable of serving either as a pivot that wallbreaks for itself and its teammates or a Choice Specs user that can tear through many teams with its power and coverage. Both sets fit on similar teams, which can make it hard to predict what Galarian Articuno is going to do and play around it. Galarian Articuno even has a nice defensive presence because of its decent bulk and recovery, with its typing also providing it useful opportunities to switch in against foes like Eldegoss and Mesprit. However, Galarian Articuno can only reliably come in on threats that are weak like Whimsicott or Choice-locked like Mesprit. This is because Pokemon like Weezing, Sandaconda, and Sandslash can either threaten it with status or super effective coverage. Galarian Articuno also struggles to break through bulky Rock- and Steel-types like Gigalith, Aggron, and Galarian Stunfisk, given its lack powerful coverage for them. Finally, due to its middling Speed tier, Galarian Articuno is outpaced and easily pressured by Pokemon such as Archeops and Sneasel.

Heavy-Duty Boots.description: This set lets Galarian Articuno serve as an offensive pivot that checks defensive Pokemon like Weezing and Sandaconda and generates momentum for its teammates. Protect is a niche alternative to U-turn that stalls a turn after using Future Sight and allows Galarian Articuno to see what move Choice item users like Sneasel and Togedemaru will lock into. However, U-turn tends to be better, since it maximizes the pressure Future Sight puts on teams. Freezing Glare can be used over Future Sight for an accurate and immediately damaging STAB move, although it's noticeably weaker. Physical wallbreakers such as Sneasel, Absol, and Trevenant appreciate Future Sight deterring their checks from switching into them and, in return, break through special walls like Gigalith and Articuno. Since many of Galarian Articuno's best checks are grounded, support from entry hazard setters such as Weezing, Ferroseed, and Froslass is very useful. These Pokemon have an easier time keeping their entry hazards up thanks to Galarian Articuno's Competitive discouraging Defog attempts, and the former two can also sponge hits from potential revenge killers like Archeops. Because of its weakness to Knock Off and reliance on Heavy-Duty Boots, Galarian Articuno should never be a team's only way to deal with Fighting-types. More reliable checks to them like Aromatisse, which can also eliminate status with Aromatherapy, are therefore important partners. It's worth noting that Heavy-Duty Boots Galarian Articuno can alternatively serve as a decent setup sweeper with Calm Mind, forgoing U-turn and opting for Freezing Glare instead of Future Sight. Such a set is more self-reliant, since it allows Galarian Articuno to more readily exploit the switches it forces.

Choice Specs.description: Future Sight becomes incredibly strong when powered up by Choice Specs but shouldn't be used as this set's only Psychic-type STAB move. Psyshock hits special walls like Audino and Lanturn harder than Freezing Glare and more reliably than Hurricane, but Freezing Glare has better overall damage output. Shadow Ball hits Steel-types for neutral damage and threatens opposing Psychic-types such as Uxie and Mesprit more consistently than Hurricane. Entry hazard control is important, since Stealth Rock prevents Galarian Articuno from freely switching in. Whimsicott is a notable remover, since it threatens common entry hazard setters like Gigalith and Regirock and can use Knock Off to soften shared checks with Galarian Articuno, such as Togedemaru. Another good example is Charizard, which pressures Steel-types and offensively checks faster Pokemon like Ribombee. Particularly, if it lacks Toxic, Charizard also enjoys Galarian Articuno overwhelming its primary switch-in in Gigalith. Setup sweepers like Sneasel and Silvally-Fairy appreciate Galarian Articuno giving them an easier time breaking through teams and finishing them off late-game. They also find Future Sight dissuading their checks and counters from switching in very useful, since this can translate to either a forced KO or more turns to set up.

Lanturn.overview: Lanturn's unique defensive typing lets it check most of the tier's prominent Electric-, Fire-, and Water-types, such as Charizard, Togedemaru, and Jellicent. Using Volt Switch to gain momentum and bring in wallbreakers is Lanturn's main appeal; however, its reliance on passive recovery means it risks easily being worn down. Other bulky Water-types in the tier such as Wishiwashi, Jellicent, and Quagsire don't suffer nearly as much from entry hazards or physical attacks, and Jellicent and Quagsire also don't need to rely on passive recovery. Even so, Lanturn sets itself apart from other bulky Water-types thanks to its rare combination of defensive utility—including an Electric immunity from Volt Absorb—and pivoting.

Bulky Pivot.description: Volt Switch brings in frailer wallbreakers like Sneasel and Archeops on Pokemon like Eldegoss and Audino, while Scald and Toxic spread status and help weaken the opposing team. Protect lets Lanturn slowly gain HP back with Leftovers and scout out potential Choice item users such as Aggron, Galarian Articuno, and Whimsicott. Heal Bell can be utilized over Protect for teammates that need to stay status free, like Silvally-Fairy and Silvally-Ghost. However, this leaves Lanturn vulnerable to aforementioned Choice item users. Lanturn benefits heavily from teammates that can keep entry hazards off the field, especially with its frequent pivoting, such as Eldegoss and Charizard. Because Lanturn is unable to beat Grass- and Ground-types such as Sandaconda, Sandslash, and Whimsicott one-on-one, it appreciates teammates like Weezing, Gourgeist-XL, and Centiskorch to help pressure them.

Quagsire.overview: Quagsire is seen on stall teams and sometimes balance teams thanks to its support moves, Unaware, and reliable recovery. With Unaware, Quagsire is able to counter many setup sweepers such as Sandslash, Silvally-Ghost, Charizard, and Sandaconda. Additionally, it fulfills a lot of role compression for said teams thanks to its wonderful defensive typing providing an Electric immunity to foes like Togedemaru and Rotom and making it an excellent switch-in to Aggron. However, Quagsire's 4x weaknesses to Grass-types and Freeze-Dry leave it unable to check certain Pokemon such as mixed Silvally formes as well as Perrserker. Furthermore, Quagsire fails to halt incredibly strong wallbreakers like Life Orb Gallade and Choice Band Sawk in their tracks due to them comfortably 2HKOing it. Lastly, Quagsire has poor Special Defense, which makes it struggle against common special wallbreakers like Vikavolt, Choice Specs Mesprit, and Whimsicott.

Unaware Wall.description: Scald is essential for Quagsire, as it burns Grass-types that can switch into its STAB moves like Shiftry and Gourgeist-S. Toxic wears down switch-ins like Whimsicott, Ribombee, and Vikavolt. Curse is another option to provide stall teams with a bulky setup sweeper. Haze is also a good option to prevent setup opportunities from foes like Ribombee and Silvally-Fairy. Heavy-Duty Boots is preferred for its ability to nullify entry hazards, since Quagsire's bulk isn't largely impressive to begin with. Taking 48 EVs from Defense and putting them in Special Defense allows Quagsire to switch into Quiver Dance Ribombee, although it makes it easier to overwhelm on the physical side. Weezing is an outstanding partner for Quagsire, as it provides a Toxic immunity and a switch-in to Grass-types like Trevenant. Audino provides cleric support and appreciates Quagsire's abilities to handle setup sweepers that take advantage of its passiveness, like Sandaconda. Charizard or Articuno makes for a fine Defogger to pair with Quagsire, as entry hazards can severely cripple Quagsire's longevity if it loses its Heavy-Duty Boots.

Qwilfish.overview: Qwilfish makes for a solid Spikes user in PU. Its high Speed tier differentiates itself from other Spikes users like Ferroseed and Garbodor, making it a good fit on more offensive teams. It is a decent switch-in to Fighting-types such as Poliwrath and works against Swords Dance Silvally formes in a pinch as well. Also, it is one of the few Toxic Spikes absorbers available. Qwilfish frequently gets opportunities to set Spikes against defensive Pokemon such as Audino and Aromatisse that cannot threaten it. However, Qwilfish is checked by common special attackers like Galarian Articuno and Charizard. Qwilfish also struggles against common entry hazard removers such as Rotom due to being worn down too fast.

Spikes.description: Taunt puts a stop to passive Pokemon like Ferroseed and Weezing. Waterfall prevents Qwilfish from being too passive and checks defensive Charizard and Centiskorch. Thunder Wave cripples Pokemon that fail to OHKO Qwilfish like Silvally formes and can also be useful against setup sweepers such as Sneasel. Poison Jab is another option that lets Qwilfish immediately threaten Whimsicott and Ribombee. Destiny Bond is handy to grab momentum on more offensive teams, as it can remove some slower wallbreakers like Trevenant. Toxic Spikes can also be used with Substitute users like Silvally-Ghost and Frosmoth. Intimidate helps against Perrserker and Silvally formes but can be a liability against Galarian Articuno, making Poison Point a fair option. Poison Point combined with Rocky Helmet can also be rather annoying for Pokemon such as Wishiwashi. Qwilfish pairs nicely with Ghost-types like Silvally-Ghost and Doublade because they spinblock, and in return they appreciate Spikes positioning them for a sweep. Rapid Spin users like Coalossal and Eldegoss synergize well with Qwilfish to keep Qwilfish's entry hazards up. Charizard appreciates both Spikes and Thunder Wave support and threatens Pokemon like Whimsicott for Qwilfish in return. Pokemon like Quiver Dance Ribombee and Swords Dance Silvally-Ghost value Qwilfish's Spikes to sweep more easily.

Sneasel.overview: Sneasel is a strong offensive threat in PU thanks to its high Speed that allows it to outpace major threats such as Archeops and near-unresisted STAB move combination in Knock Off and Triple Axel, which are powerful enough to make up for Sneasel's lacking Attack stat. Sneasel can further improve its damage output with Swords Dance or Choice Band. However, even with these options, Sneasel can struggle to break through walls like Weezing and Aromatisse. Sneasel's bulk is very low, making it difficult to switch into even the most passive defensive Pokemon, such as Eldegoss. It also doesn't help that not running Heavy-Duty Boots leaves Sneasel extremely vulnerable to all forms of entry hazards, while running it leaves Sneasel somewhat weaker and more vulnerable to status. Sneasel also faces competition from other fast revenge killers such as Archeops and Whimsicott, which have more switch-in opportunities and pivoting. Nevertheless, nothing in the tier can rival Sneasel's combination of typing, Speed, and powerful STAB combination.

Swords Dance.description: Due to Sneasel's weakness to Stealth Rock and susceptibility to all other entry hazards, Heavy-Duty Boots is the primary option for its held item. However, Life Orb can be used for an easier time sweeping, and Lum Berry gives Sneasel a one-time out from being crippled by status from the likes of Weezing and Jellicent. Sneasel rarely wants to directly switch into attacks, so it is best brought in as a revenge killer or through pivots such as Silvally-Fairy and Whimsicott. Both of these Pokemon are able to remove entry hazards and can also check Fighting-types like Poliwrath, which can cause trouble for Sneasel. These Fighting-types, as well as defensive threats like Weezing and Silvally-Steel, should be taken out or greatly weakened for Sneasel before it starts setting up. Wallbreakers such as Charizard and Archeops are ideal for this role. Spikes setters and Rocky Helmet users such as Qwilfish and Druddigon are also ideal for dealing chip damage to Choice Scarf users such as Togedemaru, ideally putting them into range of Sneasel's +2 Ice Shard before it starts setting up.

Choice Band.description: Choice Band gives Sneasel a good amount of raw power to spam its STAB moves. Low Kick provides coverage for various Pokemon that would take longer for Sneasel to wear down, such as Regirock and Aggron. Similarly to its Swords Dance set, Sneasel has difficulty hard switching in and is therefore best brought in as a revenge killer or through pivots such as Lanturn and defensive Mesprit. Because full control over the entry hazard game is difficult, Sneasel will either want very effective entry hazard removers or setters. Capable entry hazard removers such as Silvally-Fairy and Whimsicott give Sneasel more chances to wallbreak and are better for teams that can bring it in more frequently. Entry hazard setters such as Ferroseed and Qwilfish make Sneasel more devastating each time it comes in but tend to also allow Stealth Rock on Sneasel's side of the field, limiting its switch-ins. Sweepers and cleaners such as Quiver Dance Ribombee and Swords Dance Doublade also make for good teammates, as they appreciate Sneasel's ability to deal heavy damage to opposing walls.

Ninjask.overview: On account of its incredibly high Speed, which is only further supplemented by Speed Boost, Ninjask is the fastest Pokemon in PU. This, alongside its access to U-turn, lets Ninjask serve as both a capable revenge killer and an effective offensive pivot. Swords Dance adds to the list of roles that Ninjask can fulfill, turning it into a sweeper that can be annoying to play around thanks to Speed Boost. However, despite having fairly powerful STAB moves, Ninjask is not particularly strong before setting up due to its mediocre Attack. Ninjask's bad bulk and weakness-laden typing also tend to limit its setup opportunities to forced switches, and it is vulnerable to priority users like Sneasel and Lycanroc.

Swords Dance.description:
Protect lets Ninjask scout for potential coverage moves or Choice Scarf users and gives it a free Speed boost. Dual Wingbeat lets Ninjask run Heavy-Duty Boots, thus making pivoting easier and safer. It's worth noting that the move hits foes twice, though, making Ninjask more susceptible to contact abilities and items like Iron Barbs and Rocky Helmet. Acrobatics is a stronger and more accurate alternative, notably always OHKOing offensive Charizard and Galarian Articuno at +2. However, opting for Acrobatics essentially requires Ninjask not to hold any item, leaving it crippled by Stealth Rock. 104 Speed EVs allow Ninjask to naturally outrun Ribombee, the fastest common Pokemon in the tier.

Ninjask fits best on offensive teams, which aren't held back too much by its defensive shortcomings and take advantage of the momentum it generates. Ninjask lacks the coverage and strength needed to deal with bulky Ground-, Rock-, and Steel-types like Quagsire, Regirock, and Aggron, so it should be paired with wallbreakers like Jellicent and Gallade. In return, Ninjask provides these Pokemon with much appreciated pivoting support, and it offensively checks threats looking to revenge kill them, such as Ribombee. Spikes support from the likes of Garbodor and Qwilfish gives Ninjask an easier time wearing down its grounded switch-ins and securing a sweep. Garbodor can also weaken softer checks to Ninjask, such as Ferroseed, if it runs Corrosive Gas. If Ninjask chooses not to hold Heavy-Duty Boots, then pairing it with entry hazard removal from the likes of Comfey and Eldegoss is a must to keep it as healthy as possible.

Sableye.overview: Thanks to its extensive utility movepool alongside Prankster, Sableye is a decent defensive Pokemon and stallbreaker. Its good physical bulk when invested allows it to check prominent physical threats like Silvally-Ghost, Doublade, and Gallade. It's also a spinblocker that stops common spinners like Eldegoss and Sandslash. However, its low special bulk and its merely okay Defense that requires full investment leaves it at the mercy of many special attackers, like Charizard, Ribombee, and Whimsicott. Dark-types like Sneasel, Shiftry, and Thievul also prevent Prankster from working, allowing them to easily set up. Sableye cannot switch into strong wallbreakers like Lycanroc and Trevenant easily, lest it risks huge damage.

Physical Wall.description: Knock Off cripples item-reliant Pokemon like Ferroseed and Charizard. Foul Play disrupts physical attackers like Silvally-Ghost and physical Archeops. With Taunt, Sableye can annoy defensive Pokemon like Qwilfish or Audino, while Encore disrupts setup sweepers like Doublade and offensive Sandslash. Sableye is primarily used on stall teams, where it can be a blanket physical wall and a stallbreaker. Special walls like Gigalith and Aggron work well with Sableye's physical bulk; they also act as blanket checks to Fairy-types like Ribombee and Comfey. Other physical walls like Weezing and Quagsire can help if Sableye gets pressured too much by shared checks like Centiskorch and Gallade. Clerics like Aromatisse and Audino can patch up Sableye's vulnerability to status, while Sableye can check attackers like Gallade and Sandslash in return.

Aggron.overview: Aggron fits as both a strong wallbreaker and defensive wall in SS PU. Its STAB moves are naturally strong, and it has a fair amount of coverage and utility moves as well. Aggron's raw strength makes Choice Band sets extremely difficult to switch into and allows even uninvested variants to do a fair amount of damage. Aggron's typing makes it a great stop to common Pokemon like Ribombee and Galarian Articuno and grants a Toxic immunity, setting itself apart from other defensive Pokemon with Stealth Rock such as Regirock and Gigalith. However, its typing can hinder it against common Pokemon such as Gallade and Sandaconda. No reliable recovery makes defensive sets vulnerable to being worn down as well.

Choice Band.description: Aggron is able to threaten most of the tier with its high base power STAB moves. Aqua Tail provides coverage for bulky Ground-types like Palossand and Sandaconda. Earthquake allows Aggron to OHKO opposing Aggron, in addition to evading chip from Rocky Helmet users such as Sandaconda. Superpower is an option to hit Ferroseed super effectively and deal more damage to Regirock, but it usually isn't worth it. Choice Band Aggron appreciates pivots such as Whimsicott and Uxie that lure passive Pokemon such as Aromatisse and Audino for it to take advantage of. Pokemon like Basculin and Archeops can exploit Aggron's typing to gain momentum, so it appreciates support from bulky Pokemon such as Jellicent and Sandaconda. Sandaconda and Uxie also spread paralysis for Aggron.

Specially Defensive.description: Aggron is great at sponging attacks from Ribombee, Mesprit, and other special attackers with limited coverage. Even without investment, its STAB moves hit hard and keep it from being passive. Protect makes playing around Choice-locked Pokemon like Gallade and Mesprit, as well as Future Sight users such as Galarian Articuno when they are paired with Pokemon that can threaten Aggron directly, much easier. Toxic is useful to wear down bulky Pokemon like Palossand and Tangela. Roar can rack up chip damage, especially when paired with Spikes from Froslass or Qwilfish. Roar also pairs amazingly with Future Sight users like Galarian Articuno to wallbreak. Wish Aromatisse and Healing Wish Mesprit are great tools to keep Aggron healthy, with the former also absorbing Knock Off for Aggron. Other Knock Off absorbers like Weezing and Qwilfish are also useful against Pokemon such as Sawk and Ferroseed. Pokemon like Charizard and Claydol, which can remove Spikes, assist Aggron in not getting worn down too quickly.

Altaria.overview: Altaria works well as a role compressor in PU thanks to its part-Dragon typing, fair bulk, and reliable recovery, which allow it to check even the most popular special attackers in the metagame, like Jellicent and Charizard. With access to both Defog and Heal Bell, Altaria can act well as entry hazard control and a cleric all in one. However, its typing leaves it weak to STAB and coverage moves from common Stealth Rock setters like Gigalith and Mesprit with Dazzling Gleam. It also tends to be quite passive, as it has neither pivot moves to gain momentum for its team nor a threatening offensive presence. On top of that, it's also easily overwhelmed due to its unimpressive stats, especially after its Heavy-Duty Boots has been removed.

Defog.description: Hurricane synergizes amazingly with Defog due to the latter lowering the foe's evasion, making Hurricane land more often. Flamethrower gets rid of Steel-types like Togedemaru, Ferroseed, and Perrserker while also hitting Grass-types like Eldegoss and Tangela. Toxic helps handle walls that neither Altaria nor its teammates can take care of easily, which may include Audino, Aromatisse, and Regirock. It especially helps against entry hazard setters like the aforementioned Regirock and Gigalith, as they have no reliable recovery, meaning Altaria wins in the long run. Even though hazard setters may have Toxic themselves, Heal Bell allows Altaria to get rid of it and act as a cleric for its entire team. Heavy-Duty Boots allows it to come in and out without worrying about Stealth Rock, letting it Defog and check Pokemon without having to constantly use Roost. The EVs critically allow Altaria to outspeed Modest Jellicent while still making it as specially bulky as possible. Altaria fits best on bulky offense or balance teams that have reliable checks to common hazard setters, so Pokemon such as Jellicent, Quagsire, Palossand, and Trevenant make for good partners. Notably, Aggron benefits from Altaria clearing hazards and bringing in Fairy- and Steel-types, as it takes care of them with Heavy Slam and Earthquake, respectively. Aggron also takes care of Pokemon like Ribombee, Glastrier, and Regirock so Altaria has an easier time on the field. A notable alternative set for Altaria is a Fire Spin plus Perish Song set. Even though it's quite gimmicky, relies on Fire Spin's imperfect accuracy, and needs the foe to lack a pivot move, it works well at taking care of foes.

Claydol.overview: Claydol's unique qualities, movepool, and typing allow it to function as an interesting form of role compression on teams. It has access to Stealth Rock and Rapid Spin, making it a solid choice for either a Stealth Rock setter or a defensive spinner, although it cannot threaten most Ghost-types. Its typing and Levitate give it important resistances to Poison-, Psychic-, and Rock-type moves, letting it pivot into these moves from Pokemon such as Weezing, Mesprit, and Aggron, as well as two important immunities to Electric and Ground; these make it a stop to Volt Switch pivots and Pokemon locked into Earthquake in a pinch, as it fares badly against most of them otherwise. However, Claydol is very passive, heavily relying on Toxic to maintain a presence. It is forced to choose between two STAB moves that are exploitable, meaning it can struggle against foes such as Golbat and Togedemaru depending on the move it chooses. Its typing is also a double-edged sword, with weaknesses to Grass, Dark, Water, and Bug, making it easy to exploit by Pokemon such as Gourgeist and Absol, and many of the Pokemon it would like to check can run these moves. Claydol also lacks recovery if it forgoes Leftovers, meaning it can be hard to check what it wants to over a long match.

Defensive.description: Psychic has solid neutral coverage as Claydol's STAB move, letting it chip Flying-types such as Archeops and Charizard, but makes it harder to threaten Dark-types. Scorching Sands can be chosen as its STAB move due to its ability to spread burns and hit Dark-types, but it loses to Pokemon such as Golbat and Weezing. Teleport allows Claydol to gain momentum against Pokemon it forces out such as Choice-locked Togedemaru. Alternatively, Protect and Leftovers give Claydol more recovery, increase Toxic damage, and scout opposing Choice-locked Pokemon. However, this gives it a worse matchup against Knock Off users such as Absol and Gallade due to the lack of Colbur Berry. The Speed investment is to guarantee outspeeding fully invested base 80s after a Rapid Spin, such as Gallade and Mesprit, crippling them with a Toxic before they can respond. Claydol likes to have defensive support from Pokemon that can handle special attackers like Rotom, Charizard, and Basculin. Lanturn can take hits from all of them and cripple them with Toxic, and Assault Vest Lanturn specifically can soak up general special hits for Claydol. Ferroseed is another option, functioning as a Toxic sponge that can also check Grass- and Water-types. In return, Claydol can reduce the chip damage Lanturn takes with Rapid Spin and deal with Ground-types such as Sandaconda for both of them. Claydol often best fits on more defensive teams due to its lack of recovery, supportive capabilities, and lacking offensive presence; as such, it appreciates the cleric and Wish support Pokemon such as Aromatisse and Audino can give it.

Absol.overview: Absol is a good wallbreaker in the PU metagame thanks to a sky-high Attack stat, a spammable STAB option in Knock Off, and options to boost its Attack in Choice Band and Swords Dance. Access to priority in Sucker Punch, which is especially potent with Swords Dance, makes it harder to revenge kill. Its wide coverage options to hit standard Dark-type checks, like Iron Tail and Close Combat for Silvally-Fairy and Regirock, and an extremely strong STAB Knock Off are its main draws over Sneasel. Unfortunately, Absol's poor bulk, few resistances, and weaknesses to common Fighting- and Bug-type moves in the tier leave it with little defensive utility. This means Absol struggles to get in, and due to its middling Speed tier as well as Sucker Punch potentially being worked around, it often gets forced out.

Choice Band.description: The fourth move of choice depends on what Absol wants to deal with. Iron Tail takes care of bulky Fairy-types such as Aromatisse and Silvally-Fairy; however, Psycho Cut lets it 2HKO Weezing after Stealth Rock and does significant damage to Fighting-types like Poliwrath. Justified is run in order to punish Knock Offs from Pokemon such as Audino; however, Super Luck means Psycho Cut will critically hit half of the time. A Jolly nature is chosen to ensure Absol can outspeed Pokemon like Modest Magmortar, but an Adamant nature hits harder. Absol has trouble getting onto the field, so slow pivots such as Uxie can remedy this issue. They also help by baiting in Absol's prey, foes such as Rotom and Palossand, making it even easier for Absol to take something down. Fighting-types such as Gurdurr and Gallade appreciate Absol's ability to weaken Poison- and Fairy-types with its coverage, making it easier for them to sweep. Absol appreciates Fighting-type checks and Pokemon that can pivot into U-turn, such as Aromatisse and Weezing, as they can punish these Pokemon that Absol dislikes.

Swords Dance.description: Iron Tail takes out Fairy-types such as Aromatisse, while Close Combat takes care of Rock-types such as Regirock and Dark-types such as Shiftry. Play Rough can be used as a middle ground to hit Fighting-types such as Gurdurr and Poliwrath on a switch-in while hitting Fairy-types harder than Close Combat, but lacks the higher power of Iron Tail or Close Combat. Life Orb is preferred, but Black Glasses gives better longevity and the ability to bluff a Choice Band set. Justified is run to punish Knock Offs from Pokemon like Uxie. However, Super Luck, when used with Psycho Cut, results in a critical hit half of the time. Sticky Webs support is heavily appreciated due to Absol's middling Speed tier, so setters like Ribombee and Vikavolt are great partners for it. Vikavolt also breaks through physical walls such as Regirock. On bulkier teams, slow pivots such as Lanturn can help Swords Dance Absol wallbreak or sweep a team by slowly wearing down its checks whilst providing setup opportunities. Hazard setters such as Palossand also help Swords Dance Absol by moving many faster threats into the range of a boosted Sucker Punch, like Silvally-Fairy. Offensive sweepers such as Quiver Dance Ribombee appreciate Absol's wallbreaking, as it makes it easier for them to clean late-game.

Regirock.overview: Regirock's incredible physical bulk, typing, and access to Stealth Rock make it a premier physical wall in the tier. It can check a multitude of threats, like Archeops, Sneasel, Togedemaru, and Centiskorch, giving it multiple opportunities to set Stealth Rock reliably. However, it struggles against common wallbreakers like Gallade and can get overwhelmed rather quickly due to its lack of reliable recovery. Lastly, it suffers from competition from Gigalith, which can switch into threats like Charizard more reliably thanks to Sand Stream giving it better special bulk.

UN UN UN (Stealth Rock).description: Thanks to its typing and splendid physical bulk, Regirock makes for a sturdy Stealth Rock setter capable of dishing out solid damage thanks to Body Press. The given EV spread allows Regirock to always avoid the 2HKO from Choice Band Aggron, while Clear Body lets it block Parting Shot. Rock Blast allows Regirock to break Substitute and Focus Sash from Pokemon like Haunter and lead Archeops, while Stone Edge hits consistently harder. Toxic gives Regirock a way to cripple walls like Jellicent, whereas Thunder Wave can be used to cripple more offensive threats such as Whimsicott. Partners that can take on special attackers like Magneton and Magmortar that Regirock struggles against are appreciated. Lanturn stands out as a solid option, being able to further support Regirock with Heal Bell. Answers to Fighting- and Grass-types like Gallade and Trevenant are also appreciated; this makes Weezing a stellar partner. Charizard is another great teammate, and it appreciates Regirock checking threats like Archeops.

Abomasnow.overview: Abomasnow's offensive typing and raw strength grant it a unique place as a wallbreaker in PU. While it struggles to compete with other Ice-types like Frosmoth and Aurorus due to its lack of sweeping capabilities and natural speed, Abomasnow's coverage allows it to disrupt PU's defensive cores. Snow Warning is a huge asset in PU as well due to the prominence of Gigalith. However, Abomasnow is extremely prediction reliant and cannot hit very hard compared to more common wallbreakers like Choice Specs Galarian Articuno and Magneton. The number of opportunities it gets to predict is finite as well given its vulnerability to entry hazards.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf grants Abomasnow more opportunities to wallbreak and check foes like Galarian Articuno and Charizard that would otherwise outspeed it.
