Earth Power has good coverage alongside Abomasnow's STAB moves, letting it hit Steel-types such as Doublade and Togedemaru. Alternatively, Focus Blast leaves Abomasnow reliant on Blizzard to wear down Doublade but hits Audino harder. Rock Slide allows Abomasnow to OHKO Charizard and Frosmoth. Wood Hammer can be run with a Naive nature to 2HKO Gigalith after Stealth Rock, but be wary of recoil, especially given Abomasnow's Stealth Rock weakness. Gallade makes for a solid partner, as it can beat foes like Audino and Togedemaru that Abomasnow can struggle to get past due to their bulk and ability to scout. Other special attackers such as Jolteon and Ribombee appreciate Abomasnow's ability to wear down Gigalith. As Abomasnow is a Grass-type that provides very little defensive utility, Pokemon that can provide a secondary Water or Electric resistance like Wishiwashi and Sandslash are useful. Sandslash is also able to provide entry hazard removal.

Magmortar.overview: Magmortar is a threatening, if niche, wallbreaker in PU thanks to its incredible coverage and very high Special Attack. These allow it to break through many special walls that aim to check Fire-types such as Regirock and Jellicent. Magmortar also has a decent Speed stat, with a Timid nature allowing it to outspeed base 80 Speed Pokemon such as non-Choice Scarf Mesprit. However, Magmortar is still outrun by many common threats such as Basculin and Silvally. Its merely fine Speed combined with its lacking physical bulk make Magmortar relatively simple to revenge kill compared to Charizard, which has much more long-term potential. Finally, Magmortar is forced to choose between being extremely vulnerable to all entry hazards and giving up a boosting item.

Wallbreaker.description: Thunderbolt hits Water- and Flying-types such as Jellicent and Charizard. Focus Blast hits Rock-types such as Gigalith and Regirock as well as Audino. The last slot is very customizable depending on your team's needs: Scorching Sands gives Magmortar a better matchup against Lanturn and opposing Magmortar while also being a safer way to hit Rock-types. Taunt prevents recovery from the likes of Jellicent and Audino as well as Stealth Rock from setters like Druddigon in a pinch. Toxic is a good source of chip damage versus walls such as Jellicent and Gigalith. Overheat is a powerful nuke for Choice Specs Magmortar. Flame Charge is another option to turn Magmortar into a late-game cleaner, although it should only be run with Heavy-Duty Boots and a Timid nature. Magmortar can switch into a few resisted hits from Pokemon such as Whimsicott and Ribombee, but it is easily worn down and better brought in by pivots such as Lanturn and Rotom. It can also switch into predicted U-turns from Pokemon like Togedemaru and Archeops to fish for a burn with Flame Body, although this can be risky. Setup sweepers such as Quiver Dance Ribombee make for great teammates that can effectively exploit Magmortar's breaking power. Magmortar greatly appreciates entry hazard removers if it opts to not run Heavy-Duty Boots: Silvally-Fairy and Rotom are good Defoggers that can also bring Magmortar in via pivoting.

Froslass.overview: Froslass makes for a capable wallbreaker thanks to its usable Attack and great Speed tier combined with its unique typing. It also has access to utility moves such as Trick and Spikes, allowing it to cripple and overwhelm its answers; it can even run a dedicated Spikes set, although it becomes much weaker without a boosting item. However, its below average Attack often leaves it over-reliant on its own Spikes to get past defensive behemoths like Regirock, while its typing and bulk leave it easily revenge killed by faster threats such as Lycanroc, Choice Scarf Togedemaru, and Sneasel as well as priority moves like Sucker Punch and Accelrock.

Choice Band.description: Triple Axel is a strong, albeit unreliable, STAB move. Icicle Crash is an option, as it's more reliable despite being weaker; it also avoids Rough Skin and Flame Body from the likes of Druddigon and Coalossal. Trick allows Froslass to cripple its answers such as Aromatisse, while Ice Shard allows it to revenge kill foes like Ribombee. Despite seeming odd on a set using a Choice item, Spikes lets Froslass take advantage of the many Pokemon it forces out. Froslass's subpar bulk means it appreciates being brought in via partners like Galarian Articuno, which also acts as a Defog deterrent and appreciates the Spikes Froslass sets. Pokemon like Quiver Dance Ribombee and Dragon Dance Charizard have an easier time cleaning late-game after Froslass has weakened down walls such as Regirock, Aromatisse, and Wishiwashi.

Spikes.description: Froslass's great Speed and typing make it a potent Spikes setter, as it's capable of pressuring common spinners such as Sandslash. Taunt prevents Pokemon like Mareanie from recovering and also allows Froslass to keep its Spikes on the field against Defog users like Silvally-Fairy. Wallbreakers like Magmortar and Archeops greatly appreciate the Spikes Froslass sets, as it gives them an easier time breaking through Gigalith and Regirock, respectively. Pokemon like Regirock, Weezing, and Lanturn can switch into threats such as Lycanroc, Aggron, and Togedemaru that force out Froslass, respectively.

Rotom.overview: Rotom is a quite versatile Pokemon thanks to its solid typing both offensively and defensively, great Speed, and decent movepool. These traits allow it to perform well as either a Choice Scarf user or a Defogger. Electric / Ghost is a near unresisted typing, barring Shiftry, which can be pivoted out against with Volt Switch. Defensively, Rotom resists or is immune to various common attacks from Pokemon such as Archeops and Sandaconda, although has to watch out for common coverage moves such as Knock Off. Rotom's Speed allows it to outspeed threatening breakers such as Nasty Plot Mesprit and for its Choice Scarf set to outspeed other common Choice Scarf users like Mesprit. There are other Electric- and Ghost-types that give it competition as a Choice Scarf user, such as Togedemaru with its valuable Steel typing, and Haunter with its higher Special Attack alongside support moves such as Destiny Bond; both also have higher speed than Rotom. However, Rotom's unique type combination and access to both Trick and Volt Switch make it a great option over the other two.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf allows Rotom to utilize its solid Speed to outspeed various other Choice Scarf users, such as Kabutops and Mesprit, as well as gain momentum with Volt Switch. While Trick is run to cripple specially defensive Pokemon that may try to switch in on Rotom, such as Lanturn and Gigalith, it can also be used to potentially put a stop to bulky setup Pokemon such as Uxie. Rotom is best used as a revenge killer or brought in by slow pivots such as defensive Mesprit and defensive Silvally-Fairy, which furthermore form a solid VoltTurn core with it. Wallbreakers such as Gallade benefit from being brought in through Rotom's Volt Switch.

Defog.description: Rotom can serve as a solid Defog user with its good matchup against various entry hazard setters such as Mesprit and Sandslash. Furthermore, it is able to cripple various other hazard setters such as Gigalith and Druddigon with Will-O-Wisp. Will-O-Wisp also powers up Hex, which should only be run alongside it. Thunderbolt is an option for the last slot if you want to give Rotom more of an offensive presence, although Pain Split is an option to increase Rotom's longevity that pairs well with its low HP stat. Colbur Berry allows for Rotom to better check Fighting-types and other Knock Off users, such as Sawk, but Heavy-Duty Boots is a secondary option so it can take no damage from Stealth Rock. While Rotom does have a nice defensive typing, it is recommended to not switch it into attacks too many times, as it is easily worn down with its only okay bulk, especially without Pain Split. Pokemon that are easily worn down by entry hazards, such as Gallade and Sandaconda, appreciate Rotom's hazard removal.

Offensive Pivot.description: Rotom-F is not viable in PU, but this is considered its most effective moveset.

Uxie.overview: Uxie's position in the metagame stems from the viability of Grassy Terrain hyper offense, which allows it to serve as a consistent sweeper with a Grassy Seed. Thanks to Stored Power and Draining Kiss, it can boost past Steel-types like Togedemaru and Aggron and get past Dark-types like Sneasel and Absol, all of which are common Psychic-type checks. Compared to competition like Swoobat and Comfey, it combines the STAB Stored Power and Toxic Spikes immunity of the former, the latter's ability to hit Dark-types super effectively, and its own formidable initial bulk, which surpasses both of theirs. With that and a solid Speed tier, it is difficult to take down, even with common offensive Pokemon like Charizard and Archeops. However, it is solely found on Grassy Terrain teams, as otherwise, it is too vulnerable to having its setup interrupted before it can sweep. It also can't deal with anti-setup options like Taunt and Encore from Pokemon like Jellicent and Sableye, and it must choose between Substitute and Rest in dealing with moves like Toxic, each of which has its own downsides. It lacks immediate power to force foes out, so even with Grassy Seed, it can be overwhelmed before it becomes a threat. Finally, some wallbreakers, such as Vikavolt and Silvally-Ghost, can use super effective STAB moves break past +1 Uxie with little support.

Grassy Seed Sweeper.description: Draining Kiss is used to hit Dark-types while gaining HP as a side benefit. Rest is the more chosen fourth move, allowing Uxie to beat Pokemon that rely on Toxic or chipping down setup sweepers to beat it, like Gigalith and Charizard. However, Rest leaves it open for offensive Pokemon like Doublade and Sandslash to take advantage of. Substitute can be used over Rest to still protect Uxie against status, as well as Leech Seed from Ferroseed, while leaving it less passive, but this lowers its limited HP pool. Remember that Uxie cannot viably run Leftovers, as it needs Grassy Seed, and it doesn't recover HP from Grassy Terrain due to Levitate. Thwackey is a mandatory partner for Uxie, as it is the only viable Grassy Terrian setter in the tier. It can also bring Uxie in with U-turn, giving Uxie an easier time to set up. Partners like Thievul and Hitmonlee, which fit well on Grassy Terrain teams, can force out Uxie's switch-ins like Gigalith and Aggron.

Mesprit.overview: Mesprit stands out as by far the most versatile Pokemon in PU thanks to its solid stat distribution, excellent ability in Levitate, and wide support movepool with moves such as U-turn, Healing Wish, Trick, Nasty Plot, and Stealth Rock. Mesprit is extremely good at role compression and can fulfill a variety of different needs for your team, although its counters rarely differ too much based on the set. While Mesprit is a solid wallbreaker and has the speed to beat out slower offensive and defensive staples like Perrserker and Weezing, it's still outpaced by a large portion of the metagame. Combined with a lack of any reliable recovery, this gives Mesprit extreme longevity issues, particularly Choice Scarf sets, which will rarely outspeed any other boosted Pokemon. Furthermore, Mesprit's special coverage can be lacking at times, as Mesprit can struggle against Steel-types such as Aggron and Togedemaru. Ultimately Mesprit's role compression can be very useful for covering weaknesses, but Mesprit will never be the best at any one role it attempts to cover.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf lets Mesprit revenge kill Pokemon such as Sneasel and Cinccino. Many different teammates appreciate Healing Wish support from Mesprit, from recovery-lacking wallbreakers like Magmortar to sweepers looking to set up twice such as Silvally-Ghost. However, Trick can be run in this slot instead to cripple bulky Pokemon that otherwise wall Mesprit such as Jellicent and check bulky setup sweepers such as Uxie. Mesprit rarely has opportunities to guarantee a safe switch in and needs to be brought in when a teammate has been KOed, via good predictions, or using pivoting. Slow pivots such as Silvally-Fairy and Lanturn are great options to safely bring Mesprit in and form a VoltTurn core. This will ideally be supplemented with a strong wallbreaker such as Sneasel or Trevenant ready to be brought in on a convenient pivot to do some damage.

Nasty Plot.description: Nasty Plot turns Mesprit into a fairly powerful wallbreaker, being able to 2HKO most of the tier after a single boost. The last moveslot is fairly customizable; Shadow Ball is Mesprit's best move for Steel-types like Togedemaru and Galarian Stunfisk, but Thunderbolt is an effective way to threaten Flying- and Water-types like Charizard and Jellicent before Mesprit sets up. Colbur Berry is the preferred item, as it makes Mesprit harder to revenge kill with Dark-types like Sneasel and Absol and fare better against Fighting-types like Gallade. Life Orb is a more powerful item that might even remove the need for Mesprit to set up, but the lack of longevity is such that Mesprit is unlikely to have many chances to wallbreak. A Timid nature allows Mesprit to outspeed Modest Magmortar among other threats, but Modest can be run for more damage output. Whimsicott is a good partner because it can use U-turn to bring Mesprit in for easy setup opportunities on Pokemon such as Weezing. Due to Mesprit's lack of longevity, it often pairs well with a secondary wallbreaker like Magmortar or Archeops to keep up offensive pressure after Mesprit has been KOed. Sweepers and cleaners such as Ribombee and Lycanroc can make good use of Mesprit's wallbreaking to clean up the opposing team.

Offensive Stealth Rock.description: Mesprit's final moveslot is largely dependent on how badly you want Healing Wish on your team. U-turn is far more useful for keeping up momentum and preventing Mesprit from becoming too predictable, but Healing Wish can be an effective way to supplement setup sweepers such as Doublade. Mesprit's best qualities are its good speed for a Stealth Rock setter and favorable matchup against several entry hazard removers such as Sandslash. Despite this set's lack of defensive investment, having few weaknesses means it often has the time to set up Stealth Rock and fire off multiple attacks. Few weaknesses and access to U-turn allow Mesprit to keep up momentum in a way few Stealth Rock users can, making it an ideal pick for more offensive teams. Its inability to deal much damage to special walls or Steel-types means that wallbreakers such as Trevenant and Charizard make for good partners. Mesprit appreciates Pokemon that can punish U-turn, such as Rocky Helmet Druddigon and Coalossal, which can discourage Pokemon like Togedemaru from freely pivoting versus Mesprit. Mesprit can also opt for a more defensively oriented spread that runs both U-turn and Healing Wish while foregoing Dazzling Gleam.

Choice Specs.description: Shadow Ball is Mesprit's best way to hit Steel- and Psychic-types, U-turn eases Mesprit's reliance on predictions while gaining momentum in the process, and Trick can cripple switch-ins such as Articuno and Galarian Stunfisk. Choice Specs Mesprit is extremely prediction reliant, so having at least one of U-turn and Trick can be vital for a safer option that does not leave Mesprit Choice locked into an exploitable attack. Even with Dazzling Gleam, Dark-types greatly hinder Mesprit's ability to freely spam Psychic, so a solid Dark-type answer such as Silvally-Fairy or Aromatisse is important. Mesprit is not the strongest wallbreaker around, so entry hazard setters such as Froslass and Regirock are advised to supplement its damage output. Weaker cleaners such as Dragon Dance Charizard and Quiver Dance Ribombee are ideal Pokemon to make use of Mesprit's wallbreaking. Mesprit will also require a solid defensive core with blanket checks such as Jellicent, Sandaconda, and Weezing ready to cover the wide variety of threats capable of revenge killing Mesprit after minimal chip damage.

Gigalith.overview: Gigalith’s excellent natural bulk in tandem with Sand Stream allows it to act as one of PU’s most widely useful Pokemon. Its typing allows it to resist common threats such as Galarian Articuno, Ribombee, and Charizard, and with base 135 Attack, it is by no means passive. However, Gigalith has no means of recovery outside of Leftovers and is prone to being worn down. Its pure Rock typing can be a detriment at times, as Pokemon such as Eldegoss can come in on it for free and proceed to remove Gigalith’s hazards while threatening it out with its STAB moves.

Specially Defensive.description: Stone Edge can be run over Rock Blast for more immediate damage, but its low PP and accuracy make it unreliable at times. Earthquake prevents Pokemon like Togedemaru and Aggron from taking advantage of Gigalith. Protect is used to scout for Choice-locked Pokemon such as Trevenant and Togedemaru, as well as to gain additional Leftovers recovery and rack up residual Sandstorm damage. Toxic can be run to cripple Pokemon such as Whimsicott and punish safe switch-ins such as Regirock and Palossand, which would otherwise come in on it for free. Sand Rush users like Sandslash and Lycanroc can more easily break through or sweep opposing teams with Gigalith's sand supporting them. Gigalith should be paired with team members that can deal with Water-, Grass-, or Fighting-types, such as Lanturn, Ferroseed, and Weezing. Lanturn is also able to support Gigalith with Heal Bell, allowing it to better check Pokemon like Charizard that commonly run Toxic, while Ferroseed can cripple switch-ins like Charizard with Knock Off while giving Gigalith switch-in opportunities. Other teammates such as Doublade and Whimsicott appreciate Gigalith’s ability to handle Fire- and Flying-types, and Whimsicott also deals with the Water- and Ground-types that give Gigalith trouble.

Swoobat.overview: Swoobat's niche simply comes from its ability, Simple. Using Calm Mind, it can snowball through teams more quickly faster than other setup sweepers such as Sandaconda and Uxie can. After Grassy Seed activation and one Calm Mind, Stored Power 2HKOes Audino, and another Calm Mind sees Gigalith, the tier's best special wall, KOed after Stealth Rock. Thanks to Calm Mind's Special Defense boosts, faster special attackers like Whimsicott and Ribombee struggle to revenge kill it, although Whimsicott can bother Swoobat with Encore. With Heat Wave, set-up Swoobat can also tear through Steel-types like Ferroseed and Doublade, which are usually solid checks to Psychic-types. Another boon for Swoobat is its great Speed tier, which makes it harder for tier staples like Charizard and Archeops to revenge kill. However, it relies on Grassy Seed to be effective, restricting it to Grassy Terrain teams. Despite Grassy Seed activation giving Swoobat Defense and denying Knock Off's damage boost, its physical bulk is overall poor, with a weakness to Stealth Rock alongside common Dark- and Rock-type moves not helping it. Finally, Swoobat can't fit both Heat Wave and Substitute on the same set, which means either it relies on teammates to remove Steel-types so it can sweep, or it becomes unable to set up on more passive Pokemon like Audino without fearing Toxic.

Simple Sweeper.description: Swoobat sets up Calm Mind most efficiently on slower defensive Pokemon that lack a status move, such as Sandslash and Eldegoss. Roost gives Swoobat reliable recovery, ensuring that random chip damage doesn't faze it, and lets it avoid super effective damage from slower Rock-types like Regirock and Aggron. Substitute protects Swoobat against common methods of incapacitating setup sweepers, like Trick + a Choice item or Toxic. Heat Wave targets Steel-types directly, OHKOing Togedemaru and Ferroseed after a Calm Mind. The given EV spread ensures a Gyro Ball from Ferroseed cannot break Swoobat's Substitute after Grassy Seed and it maximizes Speed for Lycanroc. Thwackey is absolutely mandatory on teams with Swoobat, as no other viable Pokemon can automatically set Grassy Terrain. On these Grassy Terrain teams, Grassy Seed + Unburden Thievul and Hitmonlee make great partners; both of them can also thrash Steel-types like Togedemaru and Aggron. Some entry hazard removers such as Coalossal can easily fit on Grassy Terrain teams and often remove Stealth Rock for Swoobat.

Audino.overview: Cleric support is often at the heart of defensive teams, and a good representative of this role is Audino. Not only can it cure status, but it also passes hefty Wishes and sponges damage thanks to Wish and Regenerator. This extensive recovery makes Audino a solid check to notable special threats like Charizard, Galarian Articuno, and Haunter. Audino has less luck versus setup special attackers like Ribombee and Meteor Beam Archeops, though, as it fails to deter their setup. Its passivity is even more notable versus physical sweepers and stallbreakers like Gallade and Centiskorch, since it lacks Defense investment.

Cleric.description: Knock Off is better than a STAB attack for Audino, as it better threatens the targets it checks like Charizard and Galarian Articuno, and item removal also deters the likes of Doublade and Choice Specs Jellicent from switching in. Heavy-Duty Boots ensures Audino maximizes the recovery netted from Regenerator, allowing it to scout attacks more safely. Hell Bell can be swapped for Toxic so that Audino is less passive against foes like Sandslash, although the team will need another cleric like Ribombee or Eldegoss given Audino's own vulnerability to Toxic. Walls like Gigalith, Regirock, and Aggron all lack reliable recovery, making them viable receivers for Wish—or Heal Bell if they opt for Rest. Their Stealth Rock support works great with Audino's Knock Off removing opposing Heavy-Duty Boots, and they also function as counters to Ribombee. Fighting-type checks like Weezing and Silvally-Fairy are always warranted as switch-ins for Gallade. Eldegoss and Tangela offer natural synergy by forming a Regenerator core, with either blanket checking physical attackers for Audino. Other physical walls such as Quagsire and Weezing are also good partners. Quagsire stands out, as it can completely quash most setup sweepers.

Sawk.overview: Among the myriad of Fighting-types in PU, Sawk tries to stand out thanks to its above average Speed tier that allows it to overcome certain threats of the tier such as Gallade, Mesprit, and Magmortar. Sawk also has very good coverage, its movepool including moves like Knock Off, Poison Jab, Stone Edge, and Earthquake which, coupled with its access to Mold Breaker allow it to defeat the most common switch-ins to other Fighting-types, such as Weezing, Charizard, and Whimsicott. Sawk is very frail though, but this problem can be handled thanks to its ability Sturdy, allowing it to survive a hit from full HP and retaliate, making it a dangerous threat to offensive archetypes. However, it has no real defensive utility, and nothing in its movepool pushes it over the edge, so Fighting-types such as Poliwrath and Gallade are often preferred over it.

Choice Attacker.description: This set makes switching into Sawk's Close Combat a really difficult task that only a few pokemon such as Aromatisse, Uxie, and Weezing can afford to accomplish. But Sawk's coverage makes up for that problem: Earthquake, paired with its ability Mold Breaker allows it to beat Weezing with Earthquake and eases prediction against Rotom, while Knock Off is good for getting rid of items, as well as hitting Psychic- and Ghost-types such as Mesprit, Doublade, and Gourgeist-S. Poison Jab rounds off the set, hitting Fairy-types such as Aromatisse and Ribombee super effectively. Sawk greatly appreciates teammates that are capable of bringing it in against Pokemon like Gigalith, Regirock, and Aggron with pivoting moves, such as Archeops and Togedemaru. Cleaners such as Ribombee really appreciate Sawk's ability to get rid of their counters such as Regirock, Gigalith, and Weezing, and Ribombee can also set up Sticky Web, making Sawk a lot harder to revenge kill. However, if Sticky Web is not set up, Sawk is rather easy to revenge kill and needs a strong defensive core to back it up. Therefore, hazard setters like Weezing and Gigalith also make for good partners, improving Sawk’s wallbreaking potential.

Sturdy Boots.description: This set makes good use of Sawk's Sturdy ability and Heavy-Duty Boots keeping it intact. Knock Off is its main coverage option, allowing it to deal good damage to Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Jellicent and Mesprit. Knock Off can also make Sawk a lot harder to revenge kill by getting rid of Choice Scarf from Pokémon such as Mesprit. Poison Jab hits Fairy-types such as Silvally-Fairy and Ribombee super effectively, and Earthquake deals good damage to Neutralizing Gas Weezing and Lanturn. This Sawk set works particularly well on offensive teams thanks to its ability to stop sweeps, as it is able to revenge kill a lot of threats such as Lycanroc and Ribombee. Cleaners such as Ribombee and Silvally-Ghost really appreciate Sawk's ability to wear down their checks such as Sandaconda and Weezing.

Whimsicott.overview: Whimsicott is a very versatile Pokemon; its good offensive Fairy typing and immaculate Speed tier let it revenge kill Pokemon such as Swords Dance Gallade, and it has a defensive presence with its great typing, Prankster, and ability to annoy opposing Pokemon with status moves. It is difficult to play around due to the unpredictability that comes with the great variety of sets it can run and its Speed. However, Whimsicott lacks the Special Attack and coverage to deal much damage. This makes it rely on utility and status moves to disrupt foes. It also lacks great defensive stats to constantly check threats such as Regirock.

Offensive.description: U-turn is used to get Whimsicott out of bad matchups, especially after using Switcheroo, when its power is lower. Psychic hits Poison-types very hard, doing massive amounts of damage to Weezing and Garbodor, while being a reliable way to hit Fire-types neutrally. Hurricane hits Fire-types harder, 2HKOing Centiskorch and usually 2HKOing offensive Charizard, but is much less reliable than Psychic. Switcheroo is used to disrupt defensive cores, as Whimsicott can force in a Pokemon such as Charizard or Togedemaru that would otherwise wall it and limit the Pokemon's counterplay by giving it Choice Specs. Pixie Plate is an alternative to Choice Specs that sacrifices strength for flexibility, making prediction less of a factor. Whimsicott offensively pairs well with Pokemon that break Fire- and Steel-types, most notably Fighting-type Pokemon that can run Rock-type coverage such as Gurdurr and Sawk. Defensively, it appreciates support from Steel-types such as Aggron and Togedemaru to switch into Poison-, Flying-, and Ice-type moves, as well as a bulky Water-types such as Jellicent and Lanturn to handle Fire- and Steel-types. With U-turn, Whimsicott can form a solid VoltTurn core with the latter partner.

Utility.description: Knock Off allows Whimsicott to remove important items such as Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots from defensive Pokemon such as Audino and Charizard, making them much less effective at checking offensive threats, while Prankster Encore deals with offensive Pokemon such as Silvally-Ghost and Frosmoth by locking them into a setup move. U-turn is a crucial move for this set, allowing Whimsicott to let wallbreakers such as Lycanroc and Aggron in on its answers like Charizard and Togedemaru, respectively. Stun Spore provides speed control against fast Pokemon such as Ribombee on the switch so that Pokemon such as Gallade can sweep much more easily. Leech Seed gives Whimsicott a form of recovery, allowing it to exploit defensive Pokemon to increase its longevity. Whimsicott pairs very well with Pokemon that like its usual Steel-, Fire-, and Flying-type switch-ins crippled, such as Frosmoth.

SubSeed.description: This set uses Prankster to its fullest potential, catching opposing Pokemon with a Leech Seed and then using Substitute before they can act. The combination of Leftovers and Leech Seed recovery almost makes up for the HP loss of using Substitute every turn, slowly draining the opposing Pokemon's HP until it's in range of a Moonblast. Psychic can be used to annoy Poison-types that can easily break its Substitute, while Knock Off is used to disrupt defensive Pokemon with recovery that can stall Leech Seed. Encore can be used to prevent setup Pokemon such as Ribombee from taking advantage of this set's passive nature while also stalling out the recovery of defensive Pokemon such as Wishiwashi. This set struggles most against Grass-types such as Tangela and Ferroseed, and Whimsicott must be wary of moves such as Dual Wingbeat from Archeops that both break its Substitute and damage it. Defensively, Whimsicott needs Pokemon such as Aggron and Galarian Stunfisk that can tank hits from Pokemon that can get past its Substitute, and these teammates can also benefit from the passive recovery that Leech Seed gives them. It also benefits from Flying- and Fire-types such as Charizard and Magmortar that deal with the Grass-types it struggles against.

Basculin.overview: With a solid Speed tier, Adaptability, and a STAB pivoting move in Flip Turn, Basculin secures its niche as a decent pivot in the tier. A Choice Scarf Basculin can outspeed the entire unboosted metagame, as well as some boosted Pokemon like Choice Scarf Mesprit and +1 Silvally-Ghost. Its decent offensive stats allow it to hit hard physically while packing a solid Ice Beam for a few physical walls, like Tangela. However, Basculin lacks ways around common Water-resistant foes like Jellicent and Eldegoss, forcing it to pivot out most times. It is also frail, limiting its ability to come in on Pokemon it would otherwise force out, like Charizard and Gigalith. Since it pivots so much, it is prone to racking up chip damage from entry hazards, Iron Barbs, and Rocky Helmet. Finally, despite having a good Speed tier, it cannot deal with Unburden + Grassy Seed users like Thievul and Hitmonlee, so it pales in comparison to Choice Scarf Ribombee on that front.

Choice Scarf.description: Crunch lets Basculin hit Jellicent super effectively, which is especially useful against Water Absorb variants, since they keep it from simply pivoting out. Superpower hits Ferroseed harder than anything else Basculin has, Ice Beam outdamages the recovery from Tangela's Regenerator—even with a Jolly nature—and Aqua Jet picks off faster foes like +1 Ninjask. Basculin struggles heavily with Water-resistant Pokemon and physically defensive walls, but it preys upon common special walls like Audino and Gigalith: partners like Galarian Articuno and Vikavolt pair well with Basculin, as they can come in on Basculin's checks, and Basculin can force out the special walls that check them. They also appreciate Basculin bringing them in with Flip Turn, forming a solid offensive pivoting core with it. Entry hazard setters like Sandslash can help Basculin wear down switch-ins like Tangela and Ferroseed, as they do not run Heavy-Duty Boots; this also helps Basculin clean late-game. Entry hazard removers like Eldegoss and the aforementioned Sandslash are equally important, as Basculin is constantly taking damage from entry hazards otherwise.

Archeops.overview: Archeops is a very threatening Pokemon in the PU tier thanks to its fantastic offensive stats, vivid movepool, and great Speed tier. Earthquake and Stone Edge give Archeops near-perfect coverage that leaves its switch-ins restricted to a marginal few, such as Claydol, Palossand, and Regirock. Archeops also has a decent defensive typing, allowing it to check foes like Charizard in a pinch; however, it is held back by its poor defensive stats. It doesn't want to be the sole defensive switch-in to any foe, preferring to pivot in on resisted attacks such as Centiskorch's Fire Lash. Defeatist is a dreadful ability that basically makes Archeops useless if it drops below 50%, further hindering its ability to hard switch into foes like Galarian Articuno well and making it very dependent on both Heavy-Duty Boots and Roost.

Meteor Beam.description: Meteor Beam in tandem with Power Herb allows Archeops to boost its Special Attack while nailing common switch-ins such as Weezing and Regirock. Air Slash 2HKOes Sandslash as well as Eldegoss after a Meteor Beam boost. Earth Power defeats Steel-type Pokemon such as non-Choice Scarf Togedemaru, Aggron, and Doublade. Archeops is a great offensive entry hazard setter, and it provides defensive utility against foes such as Charizard. Heat Wave can be used as well to defeat Ferroseed and Frosmoth. Roost is an alternative to both Stealth Rock and Heat Wave for Archeops to stay out of Defeatist range. Teammates such as Frosmoth and Ribombee appreciate the damage Archeops provides against bulky Pokemon such as Gigalith and Aggron; Frosmoth is able to defeat Ground-types that Archeops struggles against, such as Sandaconda. Other teammates such as Doublade can help switch into foes that Archeops is forced out by, such as opposing Ribombee.

Heavy-Duty Boots.description: U-turn is the preferred option in the third slot to generate momentum against foes like Palossand. Dual Wingbeat is an option that significantly pressures Grass-types like Eldegoss and Tangela as well as picking off offensive Grass- and Fighting-types like Trevenant and Gallade more reliably. Roost is necessary to offset HP loss that activates Defeatist. Heavy-Duty Boots is another important tool that prevents Archeops's Stealth Rock weakness from wearing it down into Defeatist range. Archeops fits best on offensive teams, and it should primarily be brought in via safe switches in to wallbreak or revenge kill threats such as Galarian Articuno and Magmortar, as its lack of defensive utility prevents it from getting many free turns otherwise. For this reason, partners with pivoting moves like Ribombee and Whimsicott work well with Archeops, and they form a pivot core if Archeops is using U-turn. Lanturn is another partner that can bring Archeops in safely, and it can absorb both Water- and Electric-type attacks aimed at Archeops as well as provide an additional check to Togedemaru. Froslass can help pressure many of Archeops's checks, like Palossand and Rhydon, thanks to its access to Spikes, notably bringing walls like Jellicent into 2HKO range of Stone Edge. Pokemon like Sneasel and Choice Specs Ribombee are problematic foes for Archeops, as they are faster and threaten to KO it, so Ferroseed and Choice Scarf Togedemaru can help pressure them.

Suicide Lead.description: Archeops is a good Stealth Rock setter on hyper offense teams. Its high Speed tier lets it block opposing entry hazard setters with Taunt, and it can KO itself with Head Smash to bring a teammate in safely and prevent Rapid Spin and Defog from removing its hazards. Focus Sash ensures that it can almost always set Stealth Rock; however, once it is brought into Defeatist range, there isn't too much value in preserving Archeops. Archeops can pretty much support every offensive threat in the tier, and it should almost always be the lead on the hyper offense teams it is used on. Nasty Plot Mesprit and Swords Dance Silvally-Fairy are offensive threats that appreciate the support Archeops provides. Galarian Articuno can punish Defog attempts with Competitive, letting it become more dangerous even if Stealth Rock gets removed. Offensive checks to Sneasel such as Ribombee are helpful because it can prevent Stealth Rock from being set with Triple Axel, assuming it lands two hits. Many of the aforementioned Pokemon can also bring Archeops in safely with U-turn to find opportunities to set Stealth Rock if it was unable to earlier on.

Garbodor.overview: Garbodor is a passable Spikes user in PU thanks to several unique qualities. For one, its good physical bulk allows it to handle dangerous attackers such as Sneasel and Centiskorch and punish them with Rocky Helmet and Aftermath, while a pure Poison typing lets Garbodor naturally check common Grass- and Fairy-types like Ribombee, Eldegoss, and Whimsicott. Garbodor sets itself apart from Weezing as a defensive Poison-type with Spikes and an overall greater offensive presence, courtesy of its better Speed, stronger attacks, and potential disruptive tools in Toxic Spikes and Corrosive Gas, which lets it slot into fast-paced teams. However, Garbodor is walled by several common Pokemon that resist Gunk Shot and shrug off Stomping Tantrum, such as Jellicent, Archeops, and especially Sandslash, which can threaten it with Earthquake and remove its entry hazards with little issue. Furthermore, Garbodor's lackluster special bulk leaves it vulnerable to powerful special attackers such as Charizard and Wishiwashi. Garbodor also faces immense competition as a Spikes user on offensive teams from Qwilfish and Froslass, as the former is a better pivot thanks to its superior typing, ability, and utility options, while the latter can utilize its Ghost typing and Speed to lay down Spikes nearly unopposed.

Spiker.description: Pain Split gives Garbodor more longevity to set Spikes, letting it take advantage of checks such as Jellicent that have naturally high HP. Stomping Tantrum gives Garbodor a way to hit Steel- and Rock-types such as Aggron and Gigalith. Alternatively, Toxic Spikes effectively pressures defensive Pokemon such as Quagsire and Regirock and pivots such as Wishiwashi, while Corrosive Gas lets Garbodor remove important items from its checks, most notably Doublade's and Ferroseed's Eviolite. 56 Speed EVs allow Garbodor to outspeed Adamant Aggron. An alternative spread of 252 HP / 120 Def / 136 Spe allows Garbodor to outspeed everything up to offensive Jellicent, giving it more opportunities to set Spikes. Garbodor can also choose to allot some of its Defense EVs into Attack to better pressure its offensive checks; a spread with 132 Attack allows it to OHKO Togedemaru with Stomping Tantrum and 2HKO most Charizard sets with Gunk Shot. Garbodor should be used alongside solid Charizard switch-ins such as Gigalith and Jellicent. Stealth Rock setters, such as the aforementioned Gigalith and Sandaconda, form excellent entry hazard-stacking cores with Garbodor. Garbodor also appreciates partners such as Ribombee and Sneasel that can pressure Sandslash and Hattrem, both of which counter Garbodor and prevent it from setting Spikes.

Cinccino.overview: Cinccino's high Speed and a colorful offensive movepool, with good utility options in Knock Off and U-turn make it a decent revenge killer and offensive pivot. It can outpace most of the unboosted metagame, including Lycanroc and Galvantula, and pick off most offensive threats after they get somewhat weakened. Cincinno can be rather annoying to switch into as well, as Bullet Seed threatens Gigalith and common physically defensive Ground- and Water- types, and a lot of Cincinno's checks such as Ferroseed and Doublade don't appreciate losing their item. It is particularly strong against hyper offense teams, which typically lack any reliable defensive counterplay. However, Cinccino's damage output is often disappointing. Without a damage-boosting item, it fails to OHKO most threats, and it cannot break through many common Pokemon such as Regirock and most of the tier's Steel-types, for example Aggron and Togedemaru. In terms of defensive utility, Cincinno doesn't offer anything whatsoever. A poor defensive typing along with low stats mean that it's almost entirely dependent on free switches.

Offensive Pivot.description:
Aside from allowing Cinccino to hit Rock-types meaningfully, Bullet Seed is super effective against a large number of physically defensive Pokemon that would otherwise switch in, like Jellicent, Sandaconda, and Quagsire. With Knock Off, Cinccino can support its team by removing important items from its checks, such as Ferroseed's Eviolite or Aggron's Leftovers. It also targets Ghost-types like Doublade. U-turn is useful for racking up chip damage; it also hits switch-ins like Eldegoss hard. Rock Blast is an option to better function as a revenge killer without a damage-boosting item, notably OHKOing Charizard and Archeops. Triple Axel also works to hit Archeops as well as Grass-types like Eldegoss and Gourgeist-S. Cinccino can also utilize Encore to break past some walls, locking them into status moves, and be a situational safety net against bulky setup sweepers like Calm Mind Mesprit. Protective Pads helps Cinccino against the tier's numerous Rocky Helmet, Iron Barbs and Rough Skin users, such as Togedemaru and Druddigon. Heavy-Duty Boots is another way of limiting the amount of passive damage Cinccino suffers. Choice Band vastly improves Cinccino's prowess as a revenge killer by allowing it to OHKO offensive Charizard, Gallade, and several less common Pokemon like Galvantula. If Cinccino is not required to outspeed anything faster than Charizard, an Adamant nature can be used over Jolly for some additional power.

With its pitiful defenses, Cinccino needs to be brought in with pivoting moves of teammates like Togedemaru and Wishiwashi. Wishiwashi, in particular, can also deal with bulky Rock-types like Regirock and walls such as Weezing and Sandaconda. Wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Jellicent can take advantage of the likes of Aggron and Garbodor, and Cinccino can bring them in safely with U-turn on a predicted switch. Spikes from setters like Sandslash and Ferroseed works very well with Cinccino, as most of its checks lack reliable recovery and get worn down quickly after Knock Off removes their Leftovers or Heavy-Duty Boots. By removing items from the likes of Doublade and wearing down Steel- and Poison-type walls, Cinccino can also benefit sweepers like Quiver Dance Ribombee and Swords Dance Silvally-Fairy.

Jellicent.overview: Jellicent is one of the best defensive Water-types in the tier. Compared to its competition in Wishiwashi and Lanturn, Jellicent brings to the table an excellent Ghost typing further enhanced by its myriad of supportive options such as Will-O-Wisp, Taunt, and Recover. Because of this, Jellicent is an effective switch-in to to various physical attackers such as Gallade and Perrserker. Jellicent also provides teams additional utility by punishing Water-types or Choice-locked attackers depending on if it's running Water Absorb or Cursed Body. Jellicent can also become an incredible offensive threat when equipped with Choice Specs thanks to its access to the rare and powerful Water Spout. However, defensive Jellicent can be rather passive due to its low offensive capabilities and reliance on status as the typical way of dealing damage. Furthermore, Jellicent struggles versus common special attackers such as Whimsicott and Vikavolt, as many of them can comfortably switch in and typically are not overly bothered by Will-O-Wisp or Toxic.

Defensive Utility.description: Will-O-Wisp is the preferred status move as a way to catch many physical attackers that threaten Jellicent such as Absol and Silvally-Ghost; however, Toxic can be used here in order to better cripple bulkier checks such as Lanturn and opposing Jellicent. Hex is preferred as the sole attacking move on this set because it pairs well with its status moves versus bulkier defensive answers such as Lanturn. Colbur Berry is the optimal item in order to weaken Knock Off from the likes of Sneasel or Gallade, but Heavy-Duty Boots can be used in order to be immune to entry hazards. 76 Speed EVs allow Jellicent to outspeed Jolly Glastrier. Gigalith makes a fantastic partner for Jellicent, as not only is it a good check to special attackers like Haunter, but with Sand Stream and hazard support, the residual damage Jellicent can spread with Will-O-Wisp and Toxic can severely cripple offensive answers like Whimsicott and Vikavolt. Conversely, Gigalith appreciates Jellicent's ability to check threats such as Perrserker and Sandaconda. Silvally-Fairy is also a fine partner, since it acts as a Knock Off absorber if Jellicent isn't running Colbur Berry and handles Dark-types such as Absol.

Special Wallbreaker.description: Water Spout is an incredibly strong, STAB-boosted move when Jellicent is at full HP and should be the move that is used most of the time, as it's able to hit the large majority of the tier, including defensive stalwarts like Sandaconda, Regirock, and Aggron, making Jellicent incredibly difficult to switch into. Special tanks like Audino can't switch into it, making the only real reliable switch-ins bulky, Water-resistant Pokemon like Ferroseed, opposing Wishiwashi, and Eldegoss. However, Shadow Ball hits these foes for neutral damage, forcing severe chip damage. Trick lets Jellicent cripple checks like Audino and Ferroseed. Surf is a strong secondary Water-type attack in case Jellicent gets worn down. Hydro Pump can also be run, as it has a higher base power, making it more difficult to switch into, notably 2HKOing Aromatisse and Tangela after Stealth Rock, but its inaccuracy makes it less reliable than Surf. Pairing Jellicent with pivots like Archeops or Togedemaru lets it get onto the field safely, usually against physical walls lured in by these pivots like Quagsire, Tangela, or Regirock. Entry hazards irritate Jellicent and weaken Water Spout, making deterring or removing teammates like Charizard, Hattrem, and Eldegoss incredibly valuable. Furthermore, it loves having entry hazard support to make it even harder to switch into, making entry hazard setters like Garbodor, Aggron, and Ferroseed valued teammates, as they also form a defensive core to handle Pokemon that offensively pressure Jellicent, such as Sneasel, Gallade, and Ribombee. Defensive answers to Electric- and Grass-types like Sandaconda, Eldegoss, and Charizard are incredibly good to cover Jellicent's weaknesses.

Galvantula.overview: Due to its great Speed, good offensive typing and coverage, and ability to threaten common entry hazard removers like Charizard and Eldegoss, Galvantula is an effective Sticky Web setter. Its access to Volt Switch in combination with these traits also makes it a decent pivot. However, Galvantula's meager Special Attack hinders its overall damage output. Opting for Life Orb does make up for this, particularly if Galvantula runs Thunder, but doing so means forgoing Heavy-Duty Boots and limiting its staying power. Galvantula also faces competition from other Sticky Web setters in Ribombee and Vikavolt. The former is better against Pokemon like Whimsicott due to its higher Speed, while the latter is much stronger, has Levitate and better bulk, and possesses similar coverage.

Offensive Support.description: Thunder is Galvantula's strongest STAB move and doesn't force it to switch out like Volt Switch does. The move's accuracy is also boosted by Compound Eyes, substantially increasing its reliability. Energy Ball can be used instead to put more pressure on Rock- and Ground-types like Regirock and Sandslash. Heavy-Duty Boots negates the effects of entry hazards, giving Galvantula an easier time switching around and annoying offensive teams. Alternatively, Life Orb can be used to bolster Galvantula's offensive presence, giving it a high chance to OHKO Pokemon like defensive Mesprit with Bug Buzz after Stealth Rock. However, losing immunity to entry hazards and taking Life Orb recoil both decrease its overall longevity. Slower wallbreakers and setup sweepers like Haunter and Doublade very much appreciate Galvantula both slowing down potential revenge killers, like Basculin, with Sticky Web and generating momentum for them with Volt Switch. Both of these Pokemon also benefit from Galvantula's ability to force damage onto shared checks like Gigalith and Sandaconda, and can annoy bulkier walls like Togedemaru in return. Rapid Spin users like Coalossal can give Galvantula's teammates easier entry without removing Sticky Web. Support from Rapid Spin users can also allow Galvantula to more comfortably use Life Orb.

Ferroseed.overview: With its typing, Eviolite-boosted bulk, and access to Spikes and Stealth Rock, Ferroseed functions as an effective entry hazard setter and good blanket check to several offensive and defensive threats, including Ribombee, non-Trick Mesprit, Gigalith, and Aromatisse. These same traits alongside Iron Barbs allow Ferroseed to annoy pivots such as Togedemaru and removers like Comfey. Despite lacking reliable recovery, Leech Seed and Ferroseed's natural immunity to Toxic and chip damage from sand can make it incredibly hard for some teams to wear down. However, prominent Pokemon like Charizard and Gallade pressure Ferroseed with their STAB moves due to its typing. Ferroseed's passivity also leaves it unable to do much in the face of setup sweepers like Sandslash, Sandaconda, and Cofagrigus. Finally, Ferroseed must exercise caution around foes like Whimsicott, Aggron, and Mesprit, since they can punish it for recklessly switching in with either super effective coverage or moves like Knock Off and Trick.

Defensive.description: Stealth Rock can be considered over Spikes to save a slot on Ferroseed's team and pressure non-grounded foes like Levitate Weezing, but Spikes tends to be more useful for reliably wearing down grounded Pokemon like Gigalith, Sandaconda, and Jellicent. Protect provides Ferroseed with additional recovery from Leech Seed and lets it scout Choice-locked foes like Poliwrath. Running a Relaxed nature and no Speed IVs maximizes the damage output of Gyro Ball, which compensates for Ferroseed's passivity. Try not to immediately use Gyro Ball too much, though, as the move has limited PP. Knock Off is an alternative utility option that punishes Charizard on the switch as well as other foes looking to take advantage of Ferroseed's passivity. However, it can be difficult to make room for, since Ferroseed's other moves are incredibly useful. Gigalith is a great partner, covering for Ferroseed's weakness to Fire, completing an entry hazard stacking core with it, and using sand to give it an even easier time wearing foes down. In return, Ferroseed switches into Water-types like Lanturn and Wishiwashi and can make up for its lack of recovery with Leech Seed. Jellicent can check Fighting-types and block Rapid Spin for Ferroseed, all while suffocating opposing walls with its utility options and Ferroseed's entry hazards. Offensive partners like Silvally-Fairy, Galarian Articuno, and Archeops pressure threats Ferroseed lets in, such as Gallade and Charizard. These teammates also benefit from their switch-ins being worn down by entry hazards, with Galarian Articuno also punishing Defog attempts with Competitive.

Accelgor.overview: Accelgor makes for a decent revenge killer given its higher Speed than everything but Ninjask. It works well as an offensive Spiker, with Knock Off accentuating this, removing pesky items such as Heavy-Duty Boots. It also provides pivoting in U-turn, acting as an early-game pivot and switching out on special walls like Audino and Lanturn as they come in. Accelgor can also serve as a deadly sweeper with Throat Spray + Bug Buzz on hyper offense, setting up while forcing crucial damage onto checks like Charizard and Garbodor on the same turn, helping other sweepers. However, Accelgor tends to be quite weak unless hitting a foe super effectively, and its meager bulk means even walls like Aromatisse often 2HKO it. It's also held back by its poor offensive typing in Bug and a weakness to common, good offensive types in Fire, Rock, and Flying. These flaws mean that Accelgor matches up poorly against entry hazard removers like Charizard and Coalossal. Accelgor also faces competition as an offensive Spiker from Froslass, which simultaneously spinblocks and boasts amazing utility options like Taunt and Destiny Bond.

Spikes.description: Knock Off makes Accelgor's Spikes more of a hassle to deal with for foes like Heavy-Duty Boots Audino while also punishing Eviolite users like Doublade on the switch. Focus Blast hits Steel- and Rock-types such as Aggron, Perrserker, and Togedemaru, and U-turn allows for pivoting. Recover can also be run to help get Spikes up against weaker defensive foes like Sandaconda lacking a Rock-type move, Audino, and Whimsicott. Sticky Hold prevents Accelgor from losing its Heavy-Duty Boots, giving it more opportunities to safely switch in and set Spikes. Archeops is a notable partner that enjoys Accelgor's pivoting and can use Spikes to enhance its wallbreaking potential. Wallbreakers that enjoy having Steel-types chipped also work amazingly with Accelgor, like Glastrier, Cinccino, and Galarian Articuno. Glastrier also checks Ninjask and appreciates the pivoting support Accelgor provides. Gallade also works well as a partner, taking on Rock- and Steel-types for Accelgor and enjoying being brought in by U-turn, since it's relatively slow.

Throat Spray.description: Focus Blast hits Steel- and Rock-types like Aggron, Togedemaru, Gigalith, and Regirock. Energy Ball hits Jellicent and Quagsire, as well as OHKOing Sandaconda at +1. Sludge Bomb allows Accelgor to revenge kill Ribombee, and it is also meant to force significant damage onto Charizard. Mud Shot is an alternative that doesn't chip Charizard, but could work to force damage on Doublade, Garbodor, and Neutralizing Gas Weezing. Doublade and Ribombee are some of the best sweepers to pair with Sludge Bomb Accelgor, as they can break past checks like Charizard and Gigalith after Accelgor wears them down. Rock-type sweepers like Lycanroc and Carracosta offer good synergy because they threaten Flying-types for Accelgor, and they rely on it to deal with defensive Water- and Grass-types, as well as faster threats like Whimsicott. +1 Bug Buzz cannot usually get past walls like Weezing and Garbodor, but its damage is significant enough for physical sweepers like Silvally formes and Doublade to clean thereafter. Physical sweepers help in return by forcing out special walls like Gigalith and Audino.

Stunfisk-Galar.overview: Galarian Stunfisk's unique typing and great bulk make it a solid switch-in to attackers like Ribombee, Togedemaru, and Vikavolt, giving it a solid niche over other Ground- and Steel-types like Sandaconda and Aggron. It can also further support its team with Stealth Rock and other support moves like Yawn. However, while its typing is at times great, it can also be a hinderance when trying to switch into threats like Frosmoth and Lycanroc that Steel- and Ground-types, respectively, usually check. Its lack of reliable recovery also makes it quite easy to overwhelm.

Specially Defensive.description: Rock Slide allows Galarian Stunfisk to beat Bug- and Flying-types like Ribombee and Archeops more reliably, although Stone Edge can also be used to always knock Archeops into Defeatist range. Yawn prevents Pokemon like Gourgeist and Sandslash from freely switching into Galarian Stunfisk, while Pain Split gives it a mean of recovery, albeit unreliable. Aromatisse makes for a stellar partner thanks to ability to check threats like Gallade for Galarian Stunfisk; it can also heal it back up with Wish, which it greatly appreciates. In return, Galarian Stunfisk checks Steel-types like Togedemaru for Aromatisse. Similarly, Weezing and Silvally-Fairy can take on Fighting-types such as Poliwrath that it struggles against. Lastly, wallbreakers and setup sweepers like Trevenant and Quiver Dance Ribombee appreciate Galarian Stunfisk providing them with more opportunities to come in via Yawn.

Druddigon.overview: Druddigon makes an effective pivot with its Dragon typing and ability in Rough Skin, which is used in conjunction with Rocky Helmet to punish U-turn and Flip Turn users like Togedemaru and Basculin. Heavy Defense investment lets it switch into notable Pokemon such as Centiskorch and Togedemaru. Druddigon also has a great supportive movepool with access to Stealth Rock and Glare. However, Druddigon is weak to common Fairy- and Ice-type attacks from Pokemon like Ribombee and Froslass, as well as lacking any reliable recovery options.

Defensive.description: Dragon Tail can be used to phaze Pokemon and rack up damage with Stealth Rock against Defoggers such as Charizard or setup sweepers such as Calm Mind Uxie. Otherwise, Dragon Claw makes a decent alternative. Glare is used to spread paralysis, mainly targeting Whimsicott and Ribombee that may try to switch into Druddigon. Earthquake provides good coverage with Dragon Tail, hitting Steel-types like Aggron and Togedemaru super effectively. Endure can be used as a way to accumulate an extra turn of Rocky Helmet and Rough Skin damage onto a foe, which can help check opposing Pokemon such as Triple Axel Sneasel in a pinch. Leftovers can be used as an alternative to Rocky Helmet to provide Druddigon with more longevity. Silvally-Fairy and other fast wallbreakers pair well with Druddigon, as Druddigon can punish fast Pokemon like Togedemaru that attempt to revenge kill them. Aggron and Charizard help to cover Fairy-types like Aromatisse and Ribombee that attempt to take advantage of Druddigon. Togedemaru is another Fairy-resistant Pokemon that can provide Wish support, which helps Druddigon stay healthy throughout a game.

Doublade.overview: Doublade's outstanding Eviolite-boosted physical bulk and great defensive typing let it check the many physical attackers in the PU tier, such as Gallade, Silvally-Fairy, and Cinccino. In a pinch, full-health Doublade can even handle strong Dark-types such as +2 Sneasel and Choice Band Absol, surviving Knock Off and hitting back hard with Close Combat, which outright OHKOs the latter. Doublade also possesses a solid Attack stat, which, in conjunction with Shadow Sneak, enables it to revenge kill weakened threats such as Galarian Articuno. Doublade's typing and priority Shadow Sneak also enable it to check Ribombee, a critical role that makes it a staple on offensive teams. Swords Dance allows Doublade to set up and sweep late-game provided its checks are weakened. However, Doublade's low Speed often forces it to take a hit before doing anything, and its poor special bulk can be taken advantage of by special attackers such as Charizard, especially if its Eviolite has been lost to Knock Off.

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance raises Doublade's Attack and enables its Shadow Sneak to clean up teams if boosted enough. Shadow Claw serves as a stronger STAB move against bulkier foes such as Jellicent and opposing Doublade, while Iron Head hits Gigalith and Regirock hard without the stat-lowering drawback of Close Combat. Rock Slide may be an alternative option for Pokemon such as Charizard that may try to switch in, and it retains good coverage alongside Close Combat. Close Combat affords perfect neutral coverage alongside Shadow Sneak or Shadow Claw while also breaking through some physically bulky Pokemon such as Aggron. 8 Speed EVs outspeed uninvested base 35 Speed Pokemon such as Quagsire. Pokemon with high special bulk to complement Doublade's physical bulk are often good teammates. Audino and Gigalith are good options on balance teams. Gigalith also provides Stealth Rock support and sand to help wear down Doublade's checks. Doublade can effectively run Rest on more bulky teams for more longevity over coverage with cleric support from Audino, Eldegoss, or Ribombee. On offensive teams, Frosmoth and Doublade can wear down each other's checks such as Regirock and opposing Doublade. Offensive Rock-types that can handle special Fire-types like Charizard, such as Archeops, may also be good teammates for Doublade on hyper offense.

Aromatisse.overview: Aromatisse is one of the bulkier Fairy-types options in the tier, capable of checking powerful Fighting-types like Gallade. Aromatisse sets itself apart from its competition thanks to the Wish and Heal Bell support it can provide its teammates, as well as an immunity to Taunt and Encore. Unfortunately, Aromatisse's mono-Fairy typing, unimpressive Special Attack stat and lack of coverage leave it prone to giving strong wallbreakers like Magmortar and Aggron a free switch-in. Aromatisse is reliant on Wish to keep itself healthy, forcing it to use Protect very often, which can be a huge momentum drain. Aromatisse faces little direct competition but teams that do not need its Wish support may wish to invest in a Fighting-type check with more utility, such as Weezing, and faster-paced teams may opt for other Fairy-types like Silvally-Fairy or Whimsicott.

Defensive.description:
Heal Bell provides Aromatisse and its teammates with cleric support. Toxic allows Aromatisse to cripple Pokemon like Gigalith and Charizard. Calm Mind is an option for the last slot to give Aromatisse a more offensive precense; however, many Fairy-resistant Pokemon such as Centiskorch and Aggron can overwhelm Aromatisse with sheer power. Aroma Veil is a useful ability that prevents Aromatisse from being shut down by Taunt and Encore. Heavy-Duty Boots is an alternative option over Leftovers to prevent Aromatisse from being worn down by entry hazards, though the passive recovery from Leftovers is generally preferred.

Aromatisse fits best on bulky offense and balance builds that value Wish support and a sturdy Fighting-type check. Pokemon like Gallade and Magmortar can pressure Spikes users like Ferroseed and Garbodor, who otherwise heavily exploit Aromatisse's passivity. In return, Aromatisse can cleanse them of status and give them easier entry with Wish support. Weezing and Jellicent can help provide a secondary Fighting-type check and can check offensive breakers like Aggron and Silvally-Steel, respectively. Gigalith and Lanturn can help check strong Fire-types such as Magmortar and Charizard that Aromatisse invites in, both also greatly valuing the Wish support Aromatisse provides.

Contrary Booster.description: Malamar is not viable in PU, but this is considered its most effective moveset.

Aurorus.overview: Aurorus carves itself a niche as a powerful Ice-type wallbreaker with coverage for a majority of the tier. With two great offensive abilities, it can fire off accurate Blizzards with Snow Warning or powerful Hyper Voices with Refrigerate. Earth Power lets it hit annoying Steel- and Rock-types like Doublade and Aggron, while Freeze-Dry blasts through bulky Water-types like Wishiwashi and Lanturn. Solid bulk also gives it surprising defensive utility despite its poor defensive typing, letting it take a neutral hit or two from Pokemon like Charizard and Vikavolt, OHKOing them in return. Meteor Beam adds another layer to Aurorus's wallbreaking capability, allowing it to switch moves while still having power behind it. However, Aurous is slow and relatively frail, hindering its ability to come in without pivot support. It also has a Stealth Rock weakness, making it quickly worn down by entry hazards. Finally, blanket special walls like Audino, Ferroseed, Gigalith, and Articuno can pivot into it and either use Toxic or hit it for super effective damage.

Choice Specs.description: Ancient Power OHKOes Fire-types like Charizard and Centiskorch. Earth Power takes down Steel-type switch-ins like Togedemaru and Aggron, as well as decently hitting Gigalith, which removes Aurorus's hail and boosts its own Special Defense with sand. Freeze-Dry deals with bulky Water-types like Wishiwashi and Lanturn, 2HKOing both. Timid sets can catch Pokemon like Adamant Centiskorch and uninvested Togedemaru, while a Modest nature provides the most power, with Blizzard always 2HKOing Audino and Earth Power having a small chance to 2HKO Gigalith after Stealth Rock. Entry hazard removers like Eldegoss and Sandslash can support Aurorus; Eldegoss running Eject Button can provide Aurorus with a free turn, while Sandslash provides Spikes support as well. Other special wallbreakers such as Charizard and Jolteon appreciate shared checks like Gigalith and Audino being weakened so they can clean more easily; Jolteon also provides pivot support with Volt Switch and likes that Aurorus threatens Ground-types like Sandaconda.

Meteor Beam.description: Rock Polish lets Aurorus outspeed the entire unboosted tier, making it a great option in conjunction with Meteor Beam, which gives it the power of a Choice Specs user while allowing it to change moves. Hyper Voice and Earth Power provide near-unresisted coverage against the tier. Freeze-Dry can be run to deal with bulky Water-types like Wishiwashi more easily; however, dropping Earth Power leaves Aurorus unable to threaten Steel-types and Gigalith meaningfully. This set fits best on more offensive teams, and on them it enjoys partners like Thwackey, Doublade, and Archeops. Thwackey can use Taunt to deny opposing entry hazards while providing Grassy Terrain support, Doublade can force out special walls like Gigalith for Aurorus, and Archeops helps wear down shared checks like Gigalith. Suicide leads like Lycanroc and Qwilfish can set entry hazards for Aurorus, giving them an easier time breaking past Pokemon like Gigalith.

Trevenant.overview: Trevenant is one of PU's most devastating wallbreakers because of its high Attack, amazing offensive typing, and powerful STAB moves in Poltergeist and Wood Hammer. Trevenant also has some useful defensive attributes that differentiate it from other offensive Ghost-types such as Gourgeist-S and Froslass. Chief among these qualities is Natural Cure, which allows it to more comfortably switch into status inducers like Quagsire and Glare Sandaconda. Furthermore, Trevenant can heal while attacking with Horn Leech, which isn't weather-dependent like Synthesis, and isn't weak to Stealth Rock like Froslass. However, Trevenant lacks the bulk and longevity necessary to make full use of these good traits. While it outspeeds most defensive Pokemon, Trevenant is still incredibly slow, which, combined with its frailty and poor defensive typing, makes it easy to pressure and limits its opportunities to safely switch in. Trevenant also faces competition as a Ghost-type wallbreaker from Gourgeist-S and Froslass, since both are faster, the former is more versatile with moves like Explosion and Flame Charge, and the latter offers vital utility in Spikes.

Choice Band.description: Earthquake lets Trevenant OHKO Aggron and 2HKO itemless Neutralizing Gas Weezing. Trick can be used to annoy defensive Pokemon like Tangela and virtually guarantee that a foe can be hit by Poltergeist, although Trevenant becomes noticeably weaker without Choice Band. Sucker Punch is another option that allows Trevenant to make up for its lackluster Speed, but it's prediction-reliant and not a good move to be locked into. While Frisk lets Trevenant scout for items and whether foes can be hit by Poltergeist, not being rendered useless by status thanks to Natural Cure is usually more useful. Using an Adamant nature maximizes Trevenant's damage output, but opting for a Jolly nature allows it to outspeed Pokemon like Jolly Aggron and Perrserker. Despite being incredibly strong, Trevenant can still struggle to take care of some physical walls like Tangela. Therefore, powerful special attackers such as Galarian Articuno and Charizard are good teammates. The former can also use U-turn to get Trevenant in safely and put immense pressure on Trevenant's answers with Future Sight, while the latter can remove entry hazards with Defog. Entry hazard support helps to wear down annoying physical walls too. In particular, Spikes setters like Qwilfish can be incredibly useful, helping Trevenant guarantee 2HKOs against Pokemon like Ferroseed with Poltergeist. Avoid pairing Trevenant with Knock Off users, since they'll prevent it from as freely using Poltergeist.

Gourgeist-Small.overview: Gourgeist-S makes for a niche speed control option thanks to its typing, offensively threatening common foes like Gigalith, Wishiwashi, and Galarian Articuno while defensively dealing with Eldegoss and Sandslash as well. Choice Scarf makes it one of the fastest speed control options— letting it finish off Pokemon such as Ribombee, Adamant Sandslash in sand, and boosted Silvally. Its decent bulk allows it to spinblock as well. However, Gourgeist-S is not nearly as strong as Trevenant, and it lacks the bulk of Jellicent and Doublade to spinblock against Pokemon like Sandslash and Eldegoss often. Gourgeist-XL hits harder and can switch into the aforementioned spinners more easily thanks to its better bulk and it always fitting Synthesis. Gourgeist-S also competes with offensive Ghost-types like Haunter and Doublade that are not reliant on Poltergeist.

Choice Scarf.description: Rock Slide allows Gourgeist-S to OHKO Charizard and Frosmoth while rounding out its coverage. Synthesis gives Gourgeist-S more longevity to switch into Eldegoss and reduces the harm of switching into Sandslash's Knock Off or Coalossal's Flamethrower. Trick cripples Pokemon that often wall Gourgeist-S such as Eldegoss, Weezing, and Altaria. Gourgeist-S fits best on bulky offense teams that require more speed control and thus cannot afford to use Trevenant. Gourgeist-S works well with other Water-resistant Pokemon like Mareanie so it does not have to risk Scald burns from foes such as Wishiwashi. Wishiwashi itself makes for a solid partner that can deal with Charizard. Gigalith similarly can cover Fire-types, while Gourgeist-S threatens Water- and Ground-types, but Gourgeist-S must mind sand reducing Synthesis recovery and letting Jolly Sandslash outspeeding it. Spikes users like Sandslash appreciate Gourgeist's ability to spinblock. Pokemon with high natural Speed like Ribombee and Jolteon allow Gourgeist to use Trick more freely.

Gourgeist-Super.overview: Gourgeist-XL theoretically secures itself a specialized niche: in a tier with popular defensive Ghost-types like Jellicent and Doublade, Gourgeist-XL stands out as the best dedicated spinblocker of the bunch thanks to its high physical bulk and valuable Grass typing, beating the tier's best spinners in Sandslash and Eldegoss one-on-one. In other functions, it ends up being a middle ground between Doublade's high physical stats and Jellicent's longevity. Gourgeist is also decently powerful, with a solid Attack stat, high-Base Power moves in Poltergeist and Power Whip, and STAB types that can tear apart common cores with Pokemon like Gigalith and Ribombee. However, what makes Gourgeist-XL subpar is that many of the tier's best offensive Pokemon, such as Charizard, Galarian Articuno, and Silvally-Ghost, can easily force it out. Synthesis, its main recovery move, heavily suffers from both its low PP and the popularity of sand, problems that don't bother Jellicent's Recover. Further, its neutrality to all entry hazards leaves it more susceptible to chip damage. Finally, as a niche, being the very best spinblocker is less valuable than Trevenant's ferocious wallbreaking or Doublade blanket checking most of the metagame, for example.

Tank.description: Power Whip is useful for threatening Ground- and Rock-types like Sandaconda and Gigalith. Poltergeist nails opposing Ghost-types like Doublade while providing solid neutral coverage with Power Whip. Shadow Sneak lets Gourgeist-XL pick off faster foes like Galarian Articuno and Silvally-Ghost. Colbur Berry helps it take Knock Off from foes like Sandslash and Gallade. Running no item helps it switch into Poltergeist users like Trevenant and opposing Gourgeist while weakening Knock Off some a bit. Spell Tag increases Gourgeist-XL's offensive potential, specifically allowing it to always OHKO Charizard and Centiskorch, as well as 2HKOing defensive Eldegoss, but worsens its defensive profile and makes it harder to spinblock Sandslash. Gourgeist-XL has weaknesses to popular Fire- and Ice-types like Centiskorch and Aurorus, so it loves partners that can switch into these Pokemon, like Qwilfish and Gigalith; in return, they appreciate Gourgeist-XL switching into Ground- and Fighting-types like Sandslash and Sawk, spinblocking the former. Qwilfish can also absorb Toxic Spikes, a detriment to Gourgeist-XL.

Vikavolt.overview: Vikavolt is a wallbreaking powerhouse, sporting a massive base 145 Special Attack stat, powerful STAB attacks, Volt Switch, and decent coverage to boot. It can also switch into threats like Eldegoss and Sandaconda thanks to its passable bulk, typing, and access to recovery. However, Vikavolt is very slow for a wallbreaker, and its Bug typing can be a hindrance, as it leaves Vikavolt unable to switch into Pokemon like Regirock that it can otherwise easily pressure. It is often outclassed by Ribombee and Galvantula as a Sticky Web setter, as their Speed tier is much more suited for the aggressive playstyle, with Galvantula also sporting the same typing and Volt Switch. Similarly, Agility sets suffer from competition from Quiver Dance Ribombee.

Offensive Pivot.description: This set takes advantage of Vikavolt's wallbreaking potential, forcing out most Pokemon slower than it such as Sandaconda and Jellicent. Although Thunderbolt is a great reliable STAB move for Vikavolt, Sticky Web can be used on more offensive teams as speed control, giving Vikavolt a few more opportunities to outspeed and pressure opposing Pokemon such as Aggron and Adamant Absol but mostly serving to support its teammates. Bug Buzz is primarily used on Vikavolt as a reliable way to hit Pokemon that Electric-type moves cannot hit as well, such as Ferroseed and Trevenant. However, Energy Ball is a useful alterative to hit Ground-types harder, such as Sandslash and Galarian Stunfisk, that may attempt to block Volt Switch. Fighting-types like Gallade and Poliwrath can offensively pressure common switch-ins like Gigalith and Regirock, while also benefitting from Sticky Web affecting Pokemon like Silvally formes and Gourgeist-Small. Other wallbreakers that appreciate the Sticky Web support like Magmortar and Trevenant make for solid partners. The former appreciates Vikavolt taking on Water-types such as Lanturn, while the latter can pressure defensive behemoths like Gigalith for Vikavolt.

Agility.description: This set uses Vikavolt's wallbreaking potential and transforms it into a late-game sweeper, using Agility to make it faster than the entirety of the unboosted metagame. Vikavolt's natural bulk and typing let it use Agility against Choice Scarf Pokemon such as Togedemaru as well as more defensive Pokemon that struggle to damage it such as Eldegoss and non-Toxic Jellicent. Mud Shot allows Vikavolt to destroy Togedemaru and Magneton before they can stall it out. Energy Ball can be used to defeat Pokemon that resist its primary attacks, such as Galarian Stunfisk, but they are more niche foes. Roost can give Vikavolt more longevity, allowing it to recover on more defensive threats to make it harder to revenge kill. Agility Vikavolt pairs well with entry hazards setters such as Spikes Froslass and Qwilfish, as these help Vikavolt force its way past difficult-to-break Pokemon such as Gigalith and specially defensive Togedemaru. It also defensively pairs well with Ground-types such as Sandslash and Sandaconda that resist Rock-type attacks from Pokemon such as Lycanroc and Regirock, since these Pokemon often stop Vikavolt from sweeping.

Ribombee.overview: Ribombee makes for an incredibly versatile threat due to its blistering Speed, good typing, and solid movepool. These traits render it capable of fulfilling multiple roles, ranging from an offensive pivot able to support its teammates with Sticky Web to a capable wallbreaker and cleaner with Choice Specs and Quiver Dance, respectively. It can also revenge kill various threats like Sneasel and Archeops. However, Ribombee struggles a lot against Steel- and Fire-types as well as specially defensive walls like Aggron, Magmortar, and Gigalith due to its average Special Attack and relative lack of coverage options.

Quiver Dance.description: Thanks to its decent coverage and great Speed, Ribombee makes for a fairly threatening setup sweeper. Roost allows Ribombee to use walls like non-Toxic Quagsire as setup fodder and helps Ribombee stay around if it loses its Heavy-Duty Boots. Aromatherapy lets Ribombee support its team and prevents it from being deterred or shut down by status. Psychic is an alternative that nails Poison-types like Weezing and Garbodor. U-turn gives Ribombee more utility early- and mid-game when its checks are still healthy. Bug Buzz can be used to hit Psychic- and Grass-types like Mesprit and Eldegoss without needing a boost, though the move has little use otherwise. Wallbreakers like Mesprit and Trevenant are vital partners; they soften up Pokemon like Gigalith, Aggron, and Charizard, making Ribombee much more of a nuisance. Due to its poor bulk, teammates that can bring Ribombee in safely like Lanturn and Togedemaru make for stellar partners; the former can also switch into Fire-types such as Charizard. Lastly, other cleaners like Doublade can set up on Ribombee's answers, and vice versa.

Choice Specs.description: Ribombee's coverage and Speed make it a potent wallbreaker and revenge killer when wielding a Choice Specs. Sticky Web is an option over U-turn for Ribombee to support its teammates, while Switcheroo lets it cripple answers like Gigalith and Togedemaru. However, U-turn is the preferred option due to it easing prediction. Cleaners like Sneasel and Gourgeist-S appreciate Ribombee weakening walls like Weezing and Aggron for them. Doublade is another great teammate, as it can also take advantage of some of the various walls that Ribombee finds itself unable to break, such as specially defensive Togedemaru. Stealth Rock and other entry hazards are a huge nuisance to this particular set; they heavily dent Ribombee and make it easier to pick off with a priority move, meaning it has a harder time revenge killing Pokemon like Sneasel and Absol. This makes entry hazard control absolutely vital, with Charizard and Sandslash standing out as great options because they also deal with threats Ribombee struggles against.

Offensive Support.description: This set makes Ribombee a capable offensive pivot capable of supporting its teammates with Sticky Web. Stun Spore allows Ribombee to cripple threats it struggles against, like Charizard, while Psychic allows it to hit Poison-types, notably Weezing. U-turn takes advantage of the switches Ribombee forces and allows it to bring it teammates against the Pokemon it invites in. Pokemon like Perrserker, Magmortar, and Aggron make for fantastic partners; not only do they greatly appreciate Ribombee's Sticky Web, but they can also easily take on threats Ribombee has a hard time against such as Togedemaru and Gigalith. Due to Ribombee's unimpressive damage output, it appreciates Spikes from partners like Froslass, which can pressure Steel-types for Ribombee and also enjoys Ribombee being able to revenge kill or cripple faster threats like Sneasel. Froslass can also switch into Rapid Spin users like Eldegoss trying to get rid of Ribombee's Sticky Web.

Lycanroc.overview: Thanks to its great Speed, great Attack, and coverage, Lycanroc has established itself as a notable offensive threat capable of revenge killing multiple tier staples such as Charizard and Ribombee, which gives it an important niche over Archeops. While it does have a great Attack and movepool, it struggles to get past physically defensive walls that aren't weak to its attacks like Tangela, Quagsire, and Sandaconda without residual damage.
