Its frailty and poor defensive typing causes it to rely on pivots like Ribombee and Rotom to enter the field safely.

All-out Attacker.description: With this set, Lycanroc makes for a great revenge killer. Close Combat targets Pokemon like Gigalith, Togedemaru, and Regirock. Sand Rush in tandem with Lycanroc's high Speed lets it outspeed and pick off weakened Sandslash under sand. If running Psychic Fangs, Lycanroc is going to find itself unable to break through Sandaconda and Doublade; partners that can take them on like Whimsicott and Gourgeist-S are therefore appreciated. They can also weaken other walls such as Weezing in order for Lycanroc to clean. In exchange, they enjoy Lycanroc pressuring Pokemon like Charizard and Sneasel for them. If running Crunch, Lycanroc struggles against Fighting-types such as Poliwrath, which makes teammates like Jellicent and Aromatisse appreciated. While Life Orb makes Lycanroc less prediction reliant, Choice Band makes it hit considerably harder while also not getting chipped down by Life Orb.

Wishiwashi.overview: Wishiwashi's amazing bulk and low Speed make it the best pivot in PU and a great glue option for many teams. It can switch into attacks from many common threats such as Doublade and Sandslash and either threaten them out with its high offensive stats or safely bring in a frailer teammate. Furthermore, Wishiwashi's ability to maintain momentum makes it much easier to fit onto teams than other bulky Water-types such as Jellicent and Quagsire, though it loses out on their better defensive typing, reliable recovery, and utility options. Schooling can be a large issue for Wishiwashi, especially since its reliance on Rest for recovery and the gamble that is Sleep Talk. Lastly, despite Wishiwashi's high bulk, common Electric- and Grass-types like Magneton and Trevenant can easily threaten it out.

Defensive Pivot.description: Scald can hit decently hard and can be used to stop Wishiwashi from being setup fodder for Pokemon like Swords Dance Sneasel and Doublade. Rest is important to minimize the chance of the Schooling deactivating while also increasing Wishiwashi's longevity. The set can alternatively be run with maximum Special Defense and Sassy nature or a mixed spread, giving it a better matchup against special Pokemon like Charizard and Meteor Beam Archeops. The 4 Speed EVs allow Wishiwashi to creep uninvested Gigalith despite the Speed-negating nature, although 0 Speed IVs are also an option to make Wishiwashi an even slower pivot. Wishiwashi is a great check against many offensive and defensive Pokemon like Sandslash and Weezing, so it can be brought in to endure their hits while weakening and potentially crippling them with a burn before pivoting to a teammate like Trevenant or Gallade to give them a chance to KO or set up. Wishiwashi can also be paired with other pivot users like Archeops and Magneton to maintain momentum while wearing down the foes. Because of Wishiwashi's weaknesses to Electric- and Grass-types such as Vikavolt and offensive Eldegoss, their respective checks like Gigalith and Charizard make for good teammates.

Mareanie.overview: Mareanie acts as a defensive pivot for balance teams. It can check special attacking threats such as Charizard, Ribombee, and Jellicent while providing team support by setting and absorbing Toxic Spikes. Mareanie's wide utility movepool can also make it annoying to switch into, though its general passivity makes it vulnerable to setup sweepers and strong attackers such as Sandslash. Mareanie also has to compete for a spot with Weezing, the premier Poison-type of the tier, which can make it difficult to justify its place on a team.

Specially Defensive Wall.description: Knock Off is the preferred last move, as it makes Mareanie slightly less passive, but the other options allow for Mareanie to answer to specific threats. Poison Jab can be run to beat Quiver Dance Ribombee while also being able to fish for poison on Pokemon immune to Scald such as Jellicent. Haze allows Mareanie to beat Doublade one-on-one, provided there are no critical hits. Infestation can be used to trap and remove defensive Pokemon such as Weezing and Eldegoss, allowing teammates such as Swords Dance Sandslash to sweep easier. A Calm nature is usually preferred, as this preserves Mareanie's Speed tier, allowing it to outspeed Doublade. However, a Sassy nature is better when running Poison Jab, as this allows Mareanie to do over 50% damage to Ribombee, meaning it can't Quiver Dance on it. Mareanie pairs particularly well with Gigalith + Sandslash cores, as Mareanie can absorb Toxic Spikes for them while dealing with the tier's Water-types such as Jellicent and Wishiwashi. Mareanie's passivity means it can be a detriment into setup sweepers that immediately threaten it, such as Sandslash. Grass-types that can handle these such as Eldegoss and Tangela are good partners.

Comfey.overview: Calm Mind and Triage-boosted Draining Kiss make Comfey a dangerous Terrain sweeper that can revenge kill weakened threats like Sandslash and Archeops while simultaneously remaining healthy. Between its typing and decent bulk, Comfey can be hard to take down and can reliably check Dark- and Fighting-types such as Sneasel and Gallade that pose a threat to Terrain teams. These same defensive traits also allow Comfey to serve as a decent bulky Defogger, trading much of its offensive presence for more self-sufficiency and utility. However, when not boosted or hitting foes super effectively, Comfey tends to be very passive due to its mediocre Special Attack. Comfey also lacks coverage for Steel-types like Doublade and Ferroseed, allowing them to easily cut its sweep short or keep entry hazards up against it. Gigalith being so common hurts defensive Comfey, since Synthesis restores less HP in sand on top of already having low PP. Other Fairy-types like Ribombee and Whimsicott generally outclass Comfey, offering much of the same utility as it while being faster, more versatile, and less exploitable.

Calm Mind.description: Stored Power nails Poison-types like Weezing, prevents Charizard and non-Haze Quagsire from walling Comfey, and hits special walls like Audino harder than Draining Kiss with enough boosts. Aromatherapy keeps Comfey and its teammates from being ruined by status, while Taunt completely shuts down slow walls like Wishiwashi and Eldegoss. Giga Drain is a niche option over Stored Power that hits harder under Grassy Terrain, threatens Gigalith, and still destroys Quagsire. Stored Power provides better coverage and tends to be more devastating, though. With 64 Speed EVs, Comfey outspeeds Jolly Sandslash. Thwackey is a required partner, immediately setting Grassy Terrain for Comfey upon switch-in. Thwackey also shares a number of checks with Comfey, mainly Poison- and Steel-types, and can weaken them for it with Knock Off and U-turn. Comfey can't deal meaningful damage to Steel-types such as Doublade and Ferroseed, so Pokemon like Thievul and Hitmonlee are valuable teammates to have. These Pokemon also more immediately threaten foes like Gigalith and appreciate Comfey annoying walls like Audino and Quagsire. Coalossal can support Comfey by both setting and removing entry hazards and taking hits from foes like Charizard and Togedemaru.

Defog.description: Rest has more PP than Synthesis, always fully restores Comfey's HP, and synergizes well with Natural Cure. However, the move virtually forces Comfey to switch out upon use lest it be totally helpless, thus offering foes free turns. 16 Speed EVs let Comfey outrun Modest Magneton. Since Comfey is walled by Steel- and Poison-types like Togedemaru and Garbodor, Pokemon like Charizard and Galarian Articuno are great teammates. Charizard notably gains the ability to drop Defog thanks to Comfey and also appreciates it switching into Knock Off, while Galarian Articuno benefits a lot from the pivoting support that Comfey provides. Pokemon that are especially vulnerable to Dark- and Fighting-types, such as Jellicent, Doublade, and Sneasel, like having Comfey to fall back on against such threats and can help make up for its passivity. Wish support from the likes of Togedemaru and Audino helps Comfey remain healthy without quickly burning through Synthesis's limited PP. These Pokemon also form a good defensive core with Comfey, switching into irksome foes like Ribombee for it. Comfey can potentially run either Aromatherapy or Toxic instead of Defog to act as a cleric or punish switch-ins like Charizard, respectively; however, such a tradeoff requires dedicating another teamslot to entry hazard removal and takes away from this set's main niche.

Pyukumuku.overview: Pyukumuku is a decent option on stall teams to ward off common setup sweepers like Ribombee, Thievul, and Sandaconda. Pyukmuku's considerable defenses combined with Unaware can make it difficult to break through. Compared to its Unaware competition in Quagsire, Pyukumuku's typing has the pros of letting it better take Seed Bomb from Perrserker and take Shadow Ball from offensive Jellicent in a pinch. However, most of the time Quagsire still has the superior typing, and it also has more versatility with its moveslots. Also, Pykukumuku is completely shut down by Taunt, which is found on the tier staple Jellicent.

Unaware Trapper.description: Block allows Pyukumuku to trap and KO foes, stalling them out with Spite or Toxic. Rest is preferred in the last moveslot so Pyukumuku is not easily worn down by Toxic Ferroseed or Gigalith, and it gives an additional form of recovery. Further, since Pyukumuku won't use PP while asleep, Rest can contribute nicely to PP stalling. Alternatively, Toxic can be useful to wear down Pokemon like Jellicent, which cannot be trapped and hates taking it on the switch, and it makes Pyukumuku not dead weight against Pokemon with pivot moves, which get around Block. Pyukumuku only fits on stall teams, and it needs sturdy walls like Audino and Aromatisse to handle Pokemon that get past Pyukumuku despite Unaware, like Galarian Articuno and Gallade. Aromatisse and Audino are also good partners, since they can provide Heal Bell support. This is especially important when not running Rest to remedy opposing Toxic. Answers to Doublade such as Charizard and Weezing are also necessary since Pyukumuku cannot trap it nor Toxic it. Consistent entry hazard removal from Pokemon such as Articuno avoids having Pyukumuku overwhelmed before it can stall out attacks too.

Silvally-Fairy.overview: Silvally-Fairy is a very versatile threat in the PU metagame thanks to a myriad of factors. Solid base 95 stats across the board and a wide movepool allow it to be easily constructed to fit a specific team's needs. With access to Defog, Parting Shot, and Thunder Wave, it can be a great support Pokemon, while access to Swords Dance and super effective coverage to hit common Fairy-type checks such as Togedemaru and Charizard let it be a great offensive Pokemon. A pure Fairy typing means it's great for checking and setting up on Dark- and Fighting-types such as Absol and Hitmonlee. Silvally-Fairy's biggest flaw is its lack of any form of recovery. It is also susceptible to all entry hazards and status afflictions, making it easy to wear down and unable to check what it needs to consistently. Finally, it cannot fit all of what it wants on one set, limiting its options.

Utility.description: Parting Shot allows Silvally-Fairy to pivot out on would-be threats such as Togedemaru and Aggron. If Defog is unneeded, then Silvally-Fairy can run a status move of its choice to cripple an opposing Pokemon. Despite the Jolly nature, Flamethrower is chosen to hit Steel-types, hitting them harder than Fire Fang. The Speed investment allows Silvally-Fairy to outspeed Timid Magmortar, in addition to slower Pokemon like Absol and Shiftry, and the rest is invested into physical bulk. Notably, it is only 3HKOed by Muscle Band Gallade's Psycho Cut. Silvally-Fairy pairs best with Steel-types, building a solid defensive core with them. Togedemaru is a great option, as it can sponge Poison- and Steel-type attacks while healing Silvally-Fairy with Wish, and, in return, Silvally-Fairy can tank Fighting-type attacks for it. Psychic- and Dark-type attackers such as Mesprit and Sneasel heavily appreciate the absence of Dark- and Fighting-type checks as well as the Parting Shot support, making it easier for them set up without fear of being punished.

Swords Dance.description: A strong STAB move, great coverage, and two boosting moves let Silvally-Fairy tear through teams. Flame Charge is not only useful for hitting Steel-types, but it lets Silvally-Fairy boost its Speed, making it harder to revenge kill by Choice Scarf users such as Mesprit and Rotom. Rock Slide allows it to OHKO Charizard, while Psychic Fangs is a niche alternative that can take out a weakened Weezing. U-turn is also an option if Silvally-Fairy finds itself in a bad situation, however this means forgoing important coverage. Swords Dance Silvally-Fairy can be used as both a sweeper and a breaker, but be aware that it struggles to break past bulky physically defensive Pokemon such as Regirock and Aggron. Wallbreakers such as Shiftry and Basculin take advantage of these due to their super effective STAB moves while also weakening Fire- and Poison-types, making them solid partners for Silvally-Fairy. Cleaners such as Sneasel and Dragon Dance Charizard also appreciate walls such as Regirock and Palossand being weakened so they can efficiently sweep.

Silvally-Ghost.overview: With access to boosting moves in Swords Dance and Flame Charge alongside a good offensive typing and strong stats, Silvally-Ghost makes for a strong setup sweeper. However, it faces stiff competition from the likes of Silvally-Fairy, which offers teams a stronger defensive typing with a plethora of useful resistances for a setup sweeper whilst maintaining the same coverage, meaning it's much more versatile and can fit on a wider variety of teams. Defensively, it falls short compared to other Ghost-types, such as Doublade and Jellicent, which provide solid secondary typings with useful immunities and, in Jellicent's case, a greater supportive movepool.

Swords Dance.description: Explosion is outstanding for its ability to provide a one-time nuke versus defensive checks such as Audino. However, U-turn can be used as a way to gain momentum against the aforementioned Ghost-resists without sacrificing Silvally-Ghost's life in the process. Substitute allows Silvally-Ghost to avoid status from the likes of Lanturn and is a strong option against Sucker Punch users like Absol, but leaves Silvally-Ghost with no way to threaten other bulky Pokemon like Quagsire. Ribombee makes a great partner thanks to its ability to not only offensively check Dark-types like Sneasel, but it also provides Sticky Web support. Additionally, Silvally-Ghost can act as a spinblocker against the likes of Eldegoss and use it as setup fodder if it lacks Sleep Powder. Fighting-types like Gallade and Poliwrath can pressure defensive checks to Silvally-Ghost such as Regirock, especially when safely brought in with U-turn.

Silvally-Grass.overview: Out of all the Swords Dance Silvally formes you may choose from, only Silvally-Grass can OHKO Unaware Quagsire. That feat is notable on hyper offense teams, and Silvally-Grass is also great at pressuring defensive staples like Wishiwashi, Regirock, Sandaconda, and Jellicent. Some passive Pokemon like Ferroseed and Eldegoss struggle even more, possibly lacking any means to deter its setup, and at +1 Speed, Silvally-Grass has the coverage to clean most teams. What is missing from Silvally-Grass's arsenal is the strength to get past Doublade and defensive Poison-types. These roadblocks are huge concerns for Silvally-Grass, as it risks never securing progress if Quagsire and Gigalith can just switch to Doublade and Weezing with minimal risk. There's also the downsides to the Grass typing, which include susceptibility to status, entry hazards, and, without boosts, faster revenge killers such as Ninjask and Sneasel. Offensively, there's also competition with other Silvally types like Fairy and Ghost, which fare better outside of bulky matchups.

Swords Dance.description: Flame Charge is crucial for cleaning late-game, and it's also necessary for hitting Grass- and Steel-types like Ferroseed and Togedemaru. Rock Slide nails most of what Multi-Attack can't: it OHKOes offensive Charizard, and it's good coverage versus the likes of Ribombee and Galarian Articuno. Specially offensive sweepers like Turtonator, Meteor Beam Archeops, and Nasty Plot Mespirit are some of the most essential teammates for Silvally-Grass. They force out the likes of Doublade, Weezing, and Garbodor while also benefiting from Silvally-Grass checking Gigalith and Sandslash. While not necessarily getting past these walls themselves, sweepers like Ribombee and Sneasel may force enough damage onto Poison- and Steel-types that they succumb to +2 Silvally-Grass. Additional physical sweepers like Swords Dance Doublade benefit from Silvally-Grass getting past Quagsire, and they are also good at forcing damage against shared checks, namely Poison-types.

Silvally-Poison.overview: Silvally-Poison is primarily a niche breaker, but can also be a Defogger. Its typing works decently in a tier with prevalent Fairy-, Grass-, and Fighting-types such as Ribombee, Eldegoss, and Hitmonlee, respectively. Silvally-Poison's Toxic immunity makes it a potent threat against passive teams, as it can freely setup on clerics such as Audino and Aromatisse and still have coverage for checks like Togedemaru. Being able to fit Grass Pledge comfortably to counter Quagsire distinguishes it from other Silvally formes. However, Silvally-Poison often is outperformed as a breaker by other Silvally formes with more intimidating offensive typings like Silvally-Ghost and Silvally-Fairy. As a Defogger, Silvally-Poison fits nicely on bulkier teams as a Knock Off and Toxic Spikes absorber; even so, it tends to get worn down over time and faces competition from other bulky Poison-types like Garbodor and Qwilfish.

Work Up.description: Silvally-Poison fits nicely on bulky offense and balance teams in need of a stallbreaker. It is great at dismantling bulky teams through Work Up. Multi-Attack allows it to muscle through specially defensive Pokemon like Articuno and Audino. Flamethrower nails Steel-types like Togedemaru and Ferroseed. Grass Pledge is useful for targeting Quagsire and Palossand. Surf, as an alternative to Grass Pledge, does more damage to Aggron in exchange for not breaking Quagsire. Ferroseed is a good partner for Silvally-Poison by providing Spikes support. They compliment each other defensively as well, as Ferroseed can switch into Psychic-types like Mesprit and Silvally-Poison can switch into Fighting-types like Hitmonlee. Jellicent is also a solid fit for dealing with opposing Fighting-types and spreading burns for easier setup later. Other partners such as Galvantula and Whimsicott can lure in defensive Pokemon like Audino for Silvally-Poison to set up on. Charizard benefits from Silvally-Poison tanking Knock Off and pressuring common defensive cores. In return, Charizard offers more immediate power and can wear down shared checks like Gigalith.

Defog.description: Defogger Silvally-Poison checks common Pokemon like Ribombee and makes for decent hazard removal on bulkier teams. The Speed investment allows Silvally-Poison to Defog before Qwilfish can Taunt it. Poison-type Multi-Attack pressures common threats like Silvally-Fairy. Flamethrower hits Steel-types like Perrserker and Ferroseed super effectively. U-turn allows Silvally-Poison to pivot without triggering Competitive Galarian Articuno. Silvally-Poison is worn down fast by entry hazards when removing them, so clerics like Aromatisse and Audino are valuable partners. Tangela and Gourgeist check common Ground-types that Silvally-Poison is vulnerable against such as Sandaconda. Unaware Quagsire nullifies the various setup sweepers in the tier and reciprocally benefits from Silvally-Poison dealing with Grass-types.

Silvally-Steel.overview: Silvally-Steel has a great movepool that includes a powerful STAB attack alongside good coverage as well as solid stats all-around, with base 95 Speed allowing it to outspeed a lot of the unboosted metagame. However, what really sets Silvally-Steel apart from other Silvally formes is its typing due to its resistances to STAB attacks from various common Pokemon like Ribombee, Galarian Articuno, and Whimsicott, allowing Silvally-Steel to more easily remove entry hazards, set up, or gain momentum. With its powerful physical STAB attack and great special coverage, Silvally-Steel can utilize Work Up to break through physical and special walls alike such as Quagsire, Ferroseed, and Gigalith. Its utility options like Defog and Parting Shot also make it a great glue option, being able to gain momentum and notably being the only Steel-type hazard remover. However. Silvally-Steel's inability to hold an item is a large hindrance, as it makes Silvally-Steel easier to wear down than other hazard removers like Eldegoss and Charizard and reduces its overall damage output. Finally, it is worth noting that while species clause can make for some mind games as to which Silvally forme you are using, is also somewhat limiting with the inability to use other viable Silvally formes like Silvally-Ghost and Silvally-Fairy.

Work Up.description: Work Up is Silvally-Steel's preferred setup move as its coverage pairs exceptionally well with its typing. Furthermore, it is preferred over Swords Dance due to its competition in Silvally-Ghost and Doublade having a better STAB typing and physical movepool, respectively. With 144 Special Attack EVs, Silvally-Steel's Grass Pledge 2HKOes Wishiwashi at +1 and has a chance to OHKO Quagsire, with the rest being put into Attack. Flamethrower rounds out the coverage, being able to hit Steel-types like Doublade and certain walls like Weezing. With Silvally-Steel's wide movepool, there are other options such as Rock Slide for taking out Charizard and Substitute for an easier time setting up and sweeping. As a sweeper, Silvally-Steel pairs well with wallbreakers like Vikavolt and Trevenant that can weaken defensive threats like Lanturn and Aggron, giving Silvally-Steel an easier time cleaning up the opposing team. On the other hand, Silvally-Steel can also act as a wallbreaker to open up opportunities for late-game cleaners like Ribombee and Sneasel. Entry hazards like Qwilfish's Spikes and Sandslash's Stealth Rock give Silvally-Steel an easier time sweeping and wallbreaking. Faster Pokemon like Charizard and Archeops can stop a weakened Silvally-Steel in its tracks, so checks and other means of crippling them like Gigalith and Sleep Powder Eldegoss can be helpful.

Utility.description: As an entry hazard remover, Silvally-Steel has the benefits of resisting Stealth Rock and being immune to Toxic Spikes. The given spread lets Silvally-Steel outspeed Timid Jellicent and Modest Magneton while furthering its ability to check special attackers like Ribombee and Whimsicott. While this set is often used for Defog alongside a better matchup against hazard setters like Ferroseed courtesy of Flamethrower, Toxic is another option for crippling threats like defensive Jellicent and Eldegoss. Parting Shot is able to keep momentum while also weakening the foe's attacks for your incoming Pokemon, although U-turn has the situational benefit of not triggering Galarian Articuno's Competitive, which already takes advantage of Defog. Other pivots like Wishiwashi and Vikavolt pair well with Silvally-Steel for maintaining momentum, with Wishiwashi and other walls such as Tangela and Audino forming a good defensive core. Audino is especially notable, since it can provide Silvally-Steel with some much-needed recovery with Wish and Heal Bell. Pokemon like Choice Specs Jellicent and Choice Band Sneasel appreciate Silvally-Steel's hazard removal and additional slow pivoting to give them free turns.

Turtonator.overview: Turtonator carves a small niche as a Fire-type on hyper offensive teams over the more commonly seen Charizard thanks to a great boosting move in Shell Smash, which allows it to outspeed most of the unboosted metagame, making it difficult to revenge kill reliably. An excellent STAB combination along with high-powered STAB moves and valuable coverage in Flash Cannon makes it incredibly dangerous after a boost. However, Turtonator is held back by its low Speed, meaning it will most likely take heavy damage before safely setting up. It also has issues breaking through many top defensive Pokemon such as Gigalith, Wishiwashi, and Jellicent. Along with this, even after a Shell Smash it is still outsped by the commonly seen Ribombee as well as Choice Scarf Pokemon such as Mesprit, and it will either have a drop in its defensive stats after a boost or take heavy hazard damage upon switching in, depending on which item it's using.

Shell Smash.description: Flash Cannon hits Fairy-types such as Silvally-Fairy hard and deals good damage to Pokemon that resist Fire such as Archeops and Gigalith without the drawback of lowering Turtonator's Special Attack. White Herb reduces damage Turtonator takes after setting up, but Heavy-Duty Boots can be used to avoid hazard damage upon switching in. One of Turtonator's best offensive checks is Ribombee, so partners that can check it are useful partners to have, such as Togedemaru and Doublade. Doublade in particular is also a great partner, as it can safely switch into Pokemon that can revenge kill Turtonator, such as opposing Lycanroc. Offensive Grass-types such as Thwackey and Silvally-Grass naturally scare out Water-types that otherwise check Turtonator, making them useful partners as well, while Frosmoth's natural special bulk allows it to safely Quiver Dance against Ribombee, and it can also set up on bulky Water-types that check Turtonator, such as Quagsire.

Togedemaru.overview: Togedemaru stands out as one of the best Choice Scarf users in the tier thanks to its solid Speed tier, great offensive and defensive typing that allows it to check Pokemon such as Archeops and Whimsicott, ability to gain momentum through U-turn, and good abilities. Its unique defensive typing and access to recovery in Wish also makes Togedemaru a useful special wall for taking on certain difficult threats such as Ribombee and Vikavolt. However, despite its excellent set of resistances, its mediocre bulk and an unreliable recovery move limits Togedemaru's ability to directly switch into threats. Sitting at base 96 Speed, it is one of the fastest Choice Scarf users and can outspeed boosted setup sweepers like Modest Ludicolo and Silvally-Fairy. However, Togedemaru fails to OHKO many of these Pokemon due to its only average Attack stat and coverage options. Togedemaru faces strong competition as a specially defensive Steel-type from Aggron and Galarian Stunfisk, who can set up Stealth Rock, and as a Wish passer from Audino due to its much higher HP stat.

Choice Scarf.description: Toxic is useful for crippling switch-ins like Quagsire and Vikavolt rather than merely pivoting out with U-turn, while Encore is more effective at annoying bulky setup sweepers such as Sandaconda. Lightning Rod is useful for pivoting into Volt Switch users such as Rotom and Vikavolt, but the chip damage from Iron Barbs is preferred if there is already an Electric-immune Pokemon on the team. Iron Barbs also helps defeat opposing Choice Scarf Togedemaru. While Togedemaru can be used throughout the match to tank some resisted hits, it is best brought in as a revenge killer or through slow pivots such as Lanturn and Silvally-Fairy, which form a VoltTurn core with it. Due to Togedemaru's poor damage output, it appreciates entry hazards from the likes of Gigalith and Froslass to help wear down its foes. Wallbreakers such as Whimsicott and Magmortar can also help wear down the opposing team so Togedemaru can potentially clean late-game, and they also serve as checks for threats to Togedemaru such as Palossand and Vikavolt, respectively.

Wish Passer.description: Iron Head is Togedemaru's attacking move of choice because it better threatens Pokemon Togedemaru is aiming to check such as Frosmoth and Whimsicott and does not leave Togedemaru unable to hit Ground-types. U-turn allows Togedemaru to slightly circumvent its passivity by pivoting on predicted switches, but Toxic cripples many Pokemon that Togedemaru cannot do much damage to such as Vikavolt. Heavy-Duty Boots significantly decreases Togedemaru's weakness to Spikes, Leftovers helps make it slightly less reliant on Wish, and Rocky Helmet in tandem with Iron Barbs allows Togedemaru to punish a wide variety of contact attackers. However, Lightning Rod is preferred to stop Volt Switch users such as Vikavolt and Rotom. 8 Speed EVs allow Togedemaru to outspeed Adamant Centiskorch and Modest Frosmoth. Togedemaru can support many teammates lacking recovery with Wish, such as Weezing and Mesprit, both of which also help against the Fighting-and Ground-types that threaten Togedemaru. Setup sweepers that can take advantage of Fighting- and Ground-types, such as Nasty Plot Mesprit and Quiver Dance Ribombee, appreciate being brought in through Togedemaru's U-turn.

Thwackey.overview: While there are better Grass-types in the tier such as Whimsicott and Trevenant, Thwackey primarily stands out with Grassy Surge, letting it support setup sweepers like Hitmonlee and making it a decent wallbreaker and revenge killer. It has limited coverage, but it can make up for that with Grassy Glide, raw strength behind its STAB Wood Hammer, and the utility of Knock Off and U-turn. However, the tier has a fair amount of Grass-resistant Pokemon that can outspeed and threaten Thwackey such as Charizard and Whimsicott. Thwackey also competes with other physical Grass-types like Gourgeist and Trevenant, which have better bulk, secondary STAB moves, more natural strength, and ability to block Rapid Spin.

Choice Band.description: Choice Band allows Thwackey to maximize its power combined with Grassy Terrain. Knock Off is able to cripple common Grass-resistant Pokemon such as Charizard and Tangela. U-turn allows Thwackey to pivot on Grass-resistant that are not heavily bothered by Knock Off such as Weezing and Silvally-Poison. Grassy Surge allows Thwackey to support setup sweepers such as Grassy Seed Hitmonlee and Swoobat. Ribombee is able to form a U-turn core with Thwackey and switch it in against bulky Water-types like Lanturn. Ribombee also appreciates Thwackey weakening Steel-types. Together, they can overwhelm Grass-resistant Pokemon like Weezing and Togedemaru. Uxie and Silvally-Fairy are reliable pivots that can switch in Thwackey to safely set Grassy Terrain again or sweepers like Hitmonlee and Thievul to set up. With Grassy Terrain, Aggron appreciates the weakened Earthquake damage and passive recovery.

Thievul.overview: Thievul's main niche stems from its ability, Unburden, which, in combination with Nasty Plot, makes it a powerful Terrain sweeper that teams can struggle to revenge kill. On top of naturally exploiting defensive Ghost-types like Doublade and Jellicent, Thievul also has coverage for Steel-types and Gigalith, both of which tend to annoy other special attackers. Thievul can also use Choice Specs to become a dangerous wallbreaker that, with proper positioning, can force many switches and capitalize on them thanks to the 2x boost Stakeout gives. However, Thievul's Speed, while decent for an offensive Pokemon, often leaves it forced out by a myriad of faster threats like Archeops and Whimsicott. Its pure-Dark typing leaves it with little switch-in opportunities due to weaknesses to common Bug-, Fighting-, and Fairy-type moves, and its poor overall bulk gives it no favors. Thievul is also heavily reliant on prediction and boosts from either Nasty Plot or Stakeout to succeed, as its Special Attack is middling and Dark Pulse has mediocre Base Power. Finally, Thievul can be blanked by special walls such as Articuno and Aromatisse, which take little from all of Thievul's common moves.

Unburden Sweeper.description: With a Grassy Seed activation, Thievul becomes a powerful sweeper on Grassy Terrain teams. Burning Jealousy hits Grass-types like Ferroseed, Whimsicott, and Eldegoss, OHKOing the former two as well as Ribombee at +2. Grass Knot OHKOes Rock-types like Gigalith and Regirock at +2 after Stealth Rock under Grassy Terrain. The EVs allow Unburden Thievul to outspeed Choice Scarf Basculin and Adamant Sandslash in sand and take a Ribombee's Moonblast from full HP, while the rest is dumped into Defense to help Thievul tank priority moves better. A Timid nature with maximum Speed allows Unburden Thievul to outspeed foes like Choice Scarf Ribombee and +2 Hitmonlee, but these are seldom seen, and it makes Thievul unable to guarantee OHKOs on defensive Whimsicott and Wishiwashi at +2. Thwackey is a mandatory partner, as it is the only viable Grassy Surge user in the tier. Entry hazards setters like Coalossal and Sandslash can both remove and set entry hazards, providing solid role compression. Other sweepers are essential: Swoobat appreciates Thievul threatening Steel- and Rock-types like Ferroseed and Gigalith while it beats other special walls like Toxic Audino for Thievul, whereas Aurorus appreciates Thievul weakening special walls like Gigalith and Wishiwashi that threaten it.

Stakeout.description: Grass Knot hits opposing Rock-types such as Regirock and Gigalith, OHKOing both with a Stakeout boost after minimal chip damage. Psychic hits Fighting-types like Poliwrath looking to take a Dark Pulse, and it is a decent midground option for Fairy-types like Silvally-Fairy and Ribombee, OHKOing the latter. U-turn allows Thievul to pivot out on switch-ins such as Audino. Thievul should be paired with Pokemon that can take advantage of special walls like Aromatisse. Fighting-types such as Gallade and Sawk are great at forcing out many special walls, as well as wearing down shared switch-ins such as Aromatisse. Faster Pokemon like Ribombee and Archeops often force Thievul out, so Pokemon that can switch into them like Aggron and Sandaconda are heavily appreciated. Aggron and Sandaconda further provide Stealth Rock. Other pivots such as Wishiwashi and Ninjask can also bring Thievul in safely, the former due to being slow and the latter because Thievul forces out its switch-ins.

Eldegoss.overview: Eldegoss is one of the best Rapid Spin users in the tier, thanks to it being able to deal with and status Ghost-types, such as Doublade and Jellicent. Eldegoss is also an excellent defensive pivot, mainly because Regenerator keeps it healthy without losing momentum. It can also check most of the Ground-, Water-, and Rock-types in the tier, such as Sandaconda, Jellicent, and Regirock, with ease because their best option is often just to status Eldegoss in some manner. Eldegoss also offers great support with moves such as Sleep Powder, Charm, Stun Spore, Leech Seed, and Aromatherapy. However, because of Eldegoss's lackluster coverage and Special Attack, it must resort to status against Pokemon that resist Grass such as Perrserker and Weezing. It struggles the most against other Grass-type Pokemon, such as Ferroseed, Whimsicott, and Trevenant, since they're immune to Sleep Powder and Leech Seed. Because pure Grass-types have so many weaknesses and because Eldegoss can't run all the moves it wants at once, Pokemon like Charizard and Doublade really take advantage of it.

Defensive Spinner.description: Giga Drain heals defensive Eldegoss, but it can instead use Grass Knot to be less passive versus common heavy Pokemon, such as Aggron, Gigalith, and Jellicent. Sleep Powder and Leech Seed are both fantastic options to annoy its non-Grass-type switch-ins. Stun Spore is a very niche option but can be very beneficial for slower wallbreakers, such as Perrserker and Arctovish. Charm is mainly used to annoy Doublade, but it can still help with other physical attackers. Heavy-Duty Boots is by far the best item choice for Eldegoss, as it tends to switch in a lot to sponge damage. Eject Button is a risky item choice but can give a free switch for a wallbreaker, and once that's done Eldegoss switches into Poltergeist. However, sometimes a free switch doesn't do anything meaningful, and Eject Button won't activate versus Knock Off. Because Eldegoss lacks the coverage to meaningfully deal with Grass-resistant Pokemon, such as Charizard and Ribombee, Pokemon like Wishiwashi and Gigalith are a big help to switch into them. Eldegoss in return checks some of their switch-ins like Sandaconda and Jellicent while keeping them status free; other Pokemon that appreciate Eldegoss's cleric support are Togedemaru, Silvally-Ghost, and Perrserker, as they all must avoid burns to function at their best.

Offensive Spinner.description: One can opt to use a much more offensive build with Eldegoss, making it less passive and harder to switch in on. Leaf Storm is Eldegoss's strongest move, but one needs to be mindful of its low PP. Grass Knot can be used to avoid this but comes with the downside of its inconsistent Base Power. This Eldegoss variant can actually harm other Grass-types such as Ferroseed, Whimsicott, and even other Eldegoss with Pollen Puff. Synthesis is an option given this set's reduced bulk and ability to keep momentum better, but it's very team and matchup dependent, and Regenerator is usually enough to keep Eldegoss healthy. 36 Speed EVs are to outspeed the common defensive Jellicent. Heavy-Duty Boots keeps this offensive variant as healthy as possible, and it's especially useful versus Toxic Spikes. Pokemon such as Togedemaru, Archeops, and Charizard make for excellent teammates, as they can help lure in Water-, Ground-, and Rock-types such as Sandaconda, Gigalith, and Jellicent for Eldegoss. Eldegoss does well on Spikes-stacking teams, appreciate how they apply pressure with entry hazards, which helps gives it momentum to pivot in and spin. Doublade, Gigalith, Sandslash, and Eldegoss make an excellent base for one of these teams, as they help cover each other's weaknesses.

Coalossal.overview: While undoubtedly niche, Coalossal possesses a few attributes to stand out among other Rock-types. Unlike other entry hazard removers such as Charizard and Silvally-Fairy, it can set hazards, and it's sturdier then both. Coalossal's Fire typing gives it an easier time dealing with Bug- and Fairy-types, such as Ribombee and Whimsicott, than other Rock-types. Additionally, Flame Body lets it punish reckless U-turn users like Ninjask and other physical attackers. However, because of its common 4x weaknesses in Water and Ground, Coalossal is incredibly vulnerable to Pokemon like Quagsire, Sandaconda, and Jellicent. Additionally, many of the Pokemon it wishes to check, such as Charizard and Centiskorch, have coverage moves to chunk it or can cripple it with either Toxic or Knock Off. For these reasons, Coalossal can only fit into teams that require its specific niches, facing heavy competition from the likes of Gigalith, Regirock, and Aggron, which are all less passive than Coalossal and can hold Leftovers due to not needing Heavy-Duty Boots. Furthermore, Aggron's Steel typing lets it better check Psychic-types.

Specially Defensive.description: Coalossal can opt for Spikes if used with another Stealth Rock setter. Rapid Spin is its claim to fame over other Rock-types. Defensive Jellicent is an ideal partner for Coalossal, as it checks Pokemon such as Poliwrath and Galarian Stunfisk for it. Ferroseed and Druddigon can stack entry hazards with Coalossal and provide extra utility, like both spreading paralysis, Ferroseed bringing Knock Off, and Druddigon checking Ground- and Fighting-types. As Coalossal appreciates checks to Water-, Ground-, and Fighting-types, like Silvally-Water, Palossand, and Gallade, Pokemon such as Whimsicott and Weezing make for good partners. Meanwhile, wallbreakers like Gallade and Trevenant appreciate hazard support from Coalossal and have good type synergy with it, as Coalossal checks the Fairy-, Fire-, and Flying-types that check Gallade and Trevenant, while the latter checks both Water- and Ground-types for Coalossal.

Sandaconda.overview: Sandaconda is able to serve as a consistent Stealth Rock user and Electric-immune Pokemon with its natural bulk and Shed Skin. With Shed Skin and Rest, Sandaconda is able to remain healthy throughout the game to check Pokemon like Gigalith, Aggron, and Togedemaru. Sandaconda also provides speed control with Glare, making it less easy to take advantage of. Sandaconda's decent Speed and Attack mean it can even commit to a Coil set, although its typing and poor Special Defense leaves it forced out by tier staples like Whimsicott. However, Sandaconda still faces some competition from Aggron as a Stealth Rock user, as it has better bulk and is usually less passive. Shed Skin is also not consistent, making it unsafe to be overly dependent on Rest.

Stealth Rock.description: Sandaconda is able to cripple Pokemon it cannot touch with Earthquake like Mesprit and Archeops with Glare. Rest is able to keep Sandaconda healthy and is more reliable in combination with Shed Skin. Rocky Helmet allows Sandaconda to wear down Pokemon such as Togedemaru. Leftovers gives Sandaconda more sustainability, but it is often switching into Knock Off from Pokemon like Absol anyway. The Speed investment allows Sandaconda to outspeed Adamant Aggron. Pokemon like Togedemaru and Lanturn are able to provide Wish and cleric support respectively so Sandaconda is less reliant on Shed Skin, and can sponge special attacks from Pokemon such as Ribombee and Charizard. In return, Sandaconda can switch into strong physical attackers like Lycanroc and Archeops. Wallbreakers such as Gallade and Magmortar are able to capitalize on Sandaconda spreading paralysis. Sandaconda can run Stone Edge over Glare to hit Flying-types like Archeops at the cost of providing less support.

Defensive Coil.description: With Coil, recovery, and the ability to expel status conditions with Shed Skin, Sandaconda becomes a dangerous threat late-game. Ground- and Rock-type moves hit the entire tier for neutral coverage. Stone Edge has more power and a higher critical hit chance but low PP, while Rock Slide has less power but higher PP, which is useful in longer games where the opponent can stall out Stone Edge PP. The Speed investment allows Sandaconda to move before Adamant Aggron, with the remainder of its EVs allocated to its special bulk. Some physical bulk could be useful to ease setup against Pokemon like Silvally formes. Grass- and Water-types such as Whimsicott and Wishiwashi prevent Sandaconda from setting up, so teammates that can switch into and threaten such foes are crucial to Sandaconda's success. Ferroseed has the bulk and typing to handle a majority of offensive Grass- and Water-types, and can take advantage of their presence as an opportunity to lay entry hazards. Charizard and Gourgeist-S similarly threaten the Grass- and Water-types that Sandaconda dislikes. These teammates also appreciate Sandaconda turning Archeops and Togedemaru into setup fodder late game, as they are forced out by both of them. Grass-type breakers like Trevenant and Gourgeist-S can bait in and wear down opposing Ground-type checks like Tangela and Weezing, while also forcing out Water-types like Poliwrath and Quagsire. Stealth Rock setters such as Gigalith can allow Sandaconda to run Coil by filling in the role of a Stealth Rock user.

Centiskorch.overview: Centiskorch makes for a great wallbreaker thanks to its fantastic movepool and great Attack, allowing it to beat most physically defensive walls and Fire-resistant Pokemon like Sandslash, Gigalith, and Jellicent. Its ability Flash Fire, decent special bulk, and typing allow it to switch into threats like Silvally-Steel and Ribombee, although its lack of recovery means it can't do so very often. However, Centiskorch's mediocre defensive typing, Speed, and Defense leave it susceptible to many faster threats like Gallade, Archeops, and Basculin, which also makes it harder to get it in the field safely.

Wallbreaker.description: Fire Lash makes Centiskorch harder to switch into, and it allows Centiskorch to get past defensive behemoths like Weezing and Jellicent more easily. Power Whip hits Ground-, Rock-, and Water-types, and Knock Off allows Centiskorch to cripple foes reliant on their items. Due to its poor physical bulk, typing, and Speed, Centiskorch greatly appreciates teammates capable of bringing it in safely; Archeops, Togedemaru, and Ribombee are great examples, as they all appreciate it weakening down their answers like Gigalith. Basculin is another great example, as it enjoys Centiskorch softening up Jellicent. Answers to Flying-, Rock-, and Water-types like Charizard, Aggron, and Tangela are greatly appreciated, as Centiskorch often finds itself forced out by them. This makes Sandslash and Ferroseed great partners as they can also support it with their Spikes, giving it an easier time wallbreaking.

Hattrem.overview: Thanks to Magic Bounce, Hattrem can deter entry hazard setters, an incredibly valuable niche due to the tier's lack of hazard removal options. It also has quite a solid offensive presence, bringing a solid Special Attack stat and good coverage options. Hattrem's utility movepool is very deep too, with good options such as Aromatherapy, Healing Wish, and Nuzzle. Furthermore, it has quite decent bulk with Eviolite and can check threats like Garbodor, Sandaconda, and Regirock. However, it's very susceptible to getting worn down over time, and it's threatened by a lot of common Pokemon in the tier, such as Jellicent and Sneasel. Furthermore, against entry hazard setters like Sandslash, Aggron, and Palossand, it can struggle to deny hazards, making it obsolete in certain matchups.

Tank.description: Giga Drain hits common Stealth Rock setters such as Gigalith, Regirock, and Sandaconda while also providing Hattrem with recovery. Healing Wish can provide its teammates with a second opportunity to beat down the opposing team, especially if they got weakened in the process of removing a check or counter. Mystical Fire gives Hattrem a way to hit Steel-types like Ferrossed and Togedemaru. If running Nuzzle, strong but slower wallbreakers are especially potent teammates. To improve its longevity, Hattrem can run Rest alongside Sleep Talk, but this does cost it two valuable moveslots. 12 Speed EVs let Hattrem outspeed uninvested base 50 Speed Pokemon, notably Regirock, Aggron, and Audino. Due to Hattrem's supportive nature, it should be run alongside powerful wallbreakers, especially those that hate entry hazards like Choice item Galarian Articuno, Sneasel, and Choice Specs Jellicent. Knock Off hurts Hattrem quite a lot, as it relies on its item quite heavily for its bulk, so Pokemon that can switch into Knock Off such as Togedemaru, Sandaconda, and Wishiwashi are incredibly valued teammates.

Perrserker.overview: Boasting a high Attack stat, two abilities that boost its damage output even further, and access to moves like Seed Bomb and Close Combat to shred the likes of Quagsire and Ferroseed, Perrserker is a very powerful wallbreaker in PU with very few safe switch-ins. In combination with its natural immunity to Toxic and sand damage, this makes for a Pokemon adept at shredding defensive cores. However, Perrserker is very slow for an offensive Pokemon, leaving it outrun and dispatched by many offensive Pokemon such as Charizard, Gallade, Archeops, and Lycanroc. This gives it a much tougher matchup against faster, more offensive teams. Its special bulk is also very lacking, so Pokemon like Galarian Articuno and Ribombee can still heavily damage Perrserker, even though it resists their STAB moves—despite being a Steel-type, Perrserker doesn't contribute much defensive value to your team.

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance lets Perrserker break through most of PU's defensive Pokemon. Seed Bomb hits the Water-types that resist Iron Head, 2HKOing Quagsire and, after Swords Dance, OHKOing Lanturn and 2HKOing Jellicent. Substitute allows Perrserker to set up on weak walls like Ferroseed and Tangela, as well as dodging Weezing and Jellicent's Will-O-Wisp. Steely Spirit boosts Iron Head's power to massive levels, allowing it to 2HKO Weezing and Tangela at +2. Fire-types like Charizard and Centiskorch are highly problematic for this set, so Rock-types like Regirock and Gigalith are great teammates for checking them. Both can also set Stealth Rock for Perrserker. Charizard can scorch the Steel-types that wall this set like Ferroseed and defensive Togedemaru, and it appreciates Perrserker smashing the aforementioned Rock-types, as well as KOing Lanturn and Jellicent. Spikes setters like Garbodor and Qwilfish can help give Perrserker an easier time wallbreaking—one layer of Spikes guarantees an OHKO on Regirock with a +2 Iron Head. Both can also switch into the Fighting-types Perrserker is weak to, such as Hitmonlee. Fast cleaners like Archeops and Ribombee can take advantage of the holes Perrserker can punch in teams.

Choice Band.description: Close Combat hits opposing Steel-types such as Aggron and Ferroseed, OHKOing the former and 2HKOing the latter. Seed Bomb hits the Water-types that resist Perrserker's STAB Iron Head, OHKOing Quagsire and 2HKOing Jellicent. U-turn allows Perrserker to scout switch-ins and safely bring in a teammate. Double-Edge OHKOes Charizard and Centiskorch on the switch if running Tough Claws, two Pokemon that otherwise switch into Perrserker with ease. Tough Claws is the preferred ability on this set, as it powers up all of Perrserker's moves bar Seed Bomb. Steely Spirit can still be used, as it allows Perrserker to 2HKO Sandaconda and Palossand with a slightly stronger Iron Head. This set serves the dual roles of wallbreaker and offensive pivot. Against more defensive teams, Perrserker can use its massive power to smash defensive Pokemon like Regirock and Gigalith, as well as switching into predicted Stealth Rock and Toxic. Against offensive teams, it's best used to check physically frail Pokemon like Galarian Articuno and Ribombee, and it can use the forced switches to safely bring in a teammate with U-turn or fire off a strong attack. Fast Pokemon like Archeops and Choice Specs Ribombee are good teammates to threaten the more offensive teams Perrserker struggles with, while Perrserker can threaten the bulkier teams they struggle with. They all also appreciate the free switches Perrserker can give them with U-turn.

Runerigus.overview: Runerigus is able to provide a fair amount of utility with its typing and ability to spread both status and entry hazards. It has the natural Defense to withstand strong attacks from Pokemon like Lycanroc and various Silvally formes. Runerigus is also capable of being a setup sweeper to become less passive and take advantage of Pokemon like Toxic Audino expecting to just wear it down. However, its typing leaves it vulnerable to common wallbreakers like Trevenant and Sneasel. Also, Runerigus cannot reliably spin block against Eldegoss and is setup fodder for Pokemon like Ribombee.

Defensive.description: Runerigus's bulk gives it a fair amount of opportunities to set up entry hazards against Pokemon like Archeops and Togedemaru. Leftovers provides passive recovery, while Colbur Berry lets Runerigus switch into Knock Off users like Gallade and Sawk comfortably. Earthquake hits Magmortar and Charizard using Roost, but Body Press can be used for more damage against switch-ins like Ferroseed while still hitting typical Earthquake targets like Regirock and Gigalith. Will-O-Wisp cripples Archeops and deters Swords Dance Silvally formes. Toxic Spikes lets Runerigus spread more status and support setup sweepers like Charizard and Gallade. Poltergeist is an alternative to hit Pokemon like Whimsicott and Ribombee as well as opposing Ghost-types like Haunter. Rest gives Runerigus some form of recovery and pairs nicely with clerics like Ribombee and Eldegoss that can threaten foes such as opposing Sneasel and Wishiwashi that Runerigus struggles against. Audino can also provide Wish support for it.

Bulky Setup Sweeper.description: Runerigus is able to further push its defensive capabilities with Iron Defense and Amnesia to become a durable setup sweeper. Full Defense investment maximizes Body Press's power, but a specially defensive spread can be used to more comfortably boost against Ribombee and Charizard. Rest is Runerigus's only means of recovery and prevents it from being worn down by Toxic. Body Press allows it to capitalize on Iron Defense further and hit extremely hard. Leftovers provides passive recovery to lessen the need to use Rest, but Chesto Berry can be used for a free Rest and to have an easier time snowballing. Runerigus is completely walled by opposing Ghost-types like Froslass and Haunter with this set, so it benefits from Dark-types like Sneasel to pressure them. Weezing can spread burns to give Runerigus more setup opportunities and use Toxic Spikes to prevent Ghost-types like Jellicent and Gourgeist from stalling it out. Fighting-types like Poliwrath and Gallade can check opposing Dark- and Ice-types like Silvally-Dark and Sneasel and draw in bulky Pokemon like Quagsire and Sandaconda that Runerigus can use as setup fodder. Runerigus is also vulnerable to Pokemon such as Trevenant and Choice Specs Whimsicott that can break past it before it can boost high enough, so offensive checks to them like Charizard and Togedemaru are appreciated.

Alcremie.overview: Alcremie is a defensive Fairy-type that can check strong Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gallade. Alcremie has some advantages over the other Fairy-types in the tier, distinguishing itself from Aromatisse with its combination of Calm Mind + Recover and from Ribombee with its better bulk and pure Fairy typing. Alcremie also learns Mystical Fire, which allows it to threaten Steel-types such as Doublade more effectively than its competition. Additionally, Alcremie's ability Aroma Veil makes it particularly difficult to stop after one or two Calm Mind boosts, as it can't be afflicted by Taunt or Encore from the likes of Jellicent and Whimsicott. However, Ribombee is usually a better choice due to its much higher Speed, while Aromatisse is bulkier overall.

Defensive.description: Calm Mind makes Alcremie a threatening sweeper, as it becomes difficult to KO after a boost. Alternatively, Mystical Fire gives Alcremie more of an immediate offensive presence, as it can punish switches into common Steel-type Pokemon such as Ferroseed and Doublade. Aromatherapy makes it difficult to stop Calm Mind Alcremie with status moves such as Toxic, and provides team support on Mystical Fire sets. Alternatively, Acid Armor can be run alongside Calm Mind, allowing Alcremie to set up on both physical attackers such as Gallade and weak special attackers such as Jellicent. However, this makes Alcremie vulnerable to status, so a similar set with Rest and Stored Power instead of Recover and Dazzling Gleam can be run instead. The valuable Aromatherapy support Alcremie provides makes defensive teammates that dislike status such as Tangela and Jellicent good partners. Alcremie's Aromatherapy also pairs well with Pokemon that regularly run Rest, such as Wishiwashi. Alternatively, it can allow some Pokemon, such as Gigalith and Ferroseed, to run Rest when they otherwise wouldn't. Alcremie also appreciates teammates that can handle powerful Poison- and Steel-type Pokemon such as Qwilfish and Silvally-Steel, which makes Doublade and Quagsire good partners.

Frosmoth.overview: Despite competition from Ribombee, with its superior typing and speed, as a Bug-type sweeper, Frosmoth makes for a niche yet threatening setup sweeper thanks to Quiver Dance and potent offensive coverage. Ice Scales also gives it many setup opportunities against special attackers such as Mesprit and Whimsicott, which differentiates it from Ribombee. Frosmoth's underwhelming Speed and physical bulk, mediocre defensive typing, and inability to hit Steel-types for significant damage render it easy to revenge kill and a liability in certain matchups.

Quiver Dance.description: Substitute allows Frosmoth to avoid status conditions from Pokemon like Lanturn while making it harder to revenge kill. Giga Drain grants Frosmoth with recovery and targets Water-types like Jellicent, as well as dealing super effective damage to Rock-types like Regirock and Gigalith. Frosmoth greatly appreciates partners that can wear down the Steel-types it struggles to get past; Choice Specs Whimsicott and Mesprit make for great options, and they can both also cripple Pokemon like specially defensive Aggron and Togedemaru by using Switcheroo and Trick, respectively. Due to its lackluster Speed tier, Frosmoth finds itself easily revenge killed by threats like Choice Scarf Togedemaru; teammates like Silvally-Ghost and Coil Sandaconda can use the aforementioned threats that Frosmoth invites in as setup fodder. Charizard can wear down Pokemon like Gigalith with Toxic and can threaten Steel-types like defensive Togedemaru.

Arctovish.overview: Arctovish is a Pokemon with middling stats and awful typing. Its one saving grace is the move Fishious Rend, which, combined with Choice Band, has tremendous wallbreaking power when Arctovish moves first. However, its Ice typing makes Arctovish weak to Stealth Rock and STAB moves from prime Fishious Rend targets, such as Gigalith, Regirock, and Aggron, requiring predictions to get in safely on them. Unfortunately, the problems don't end there. Arctovish's low Speed means faster attackers such as Silvally-Fairy and Mesprit will often win one-on-one. Other slow wallbreakers such as Centiskorch and Trevenant have considerably easier times getting in on defensive Pokemon like Eldegoss. There's also the ever-prevalent Jellicent, which thoroughly shuts down Fishious Rend.

Use Fishious Rend.description: To utilize Arctovish to its fullest, besides using Fishious Rend, predict when opponents will try to check it with a Water-immune Pokemon like Jellicent, Poliwrath, or Arctovish. Then, using a coverage move or switching to a teammate is imperative. The most common roadblock for Arctovish is going to be Jellicent, so Crunch is always needed; it also helps out with certain faster attackers such as Silvally-Ghost and Mesprit. Psychic Fangs is only truly needed for niche Psychic-weak Pokemon like Poliwrath and Qwilfish, as both of Arctovish's STAB moves deal with other targets far more reliably. Because Fishious Rend doubles in power, the Water-resistant Pokemon able to come in on Arctovish are very limited: Pokemon such as Eldegoss, Ferroseed, and Wishiwashi all must stay healthy to switch in on Fishious Rend, and Grass-types such as Eldegoss and Tangela have to risk swapping into Icicle Crash. A Choice Scarf set isn't worthwhile despite Arctovish's relatively low Speed, as it loses the power needed to break through the previously mentioned Water-resistant Pokemon and still fails to outspeed fast Pokemon like Galvantula, Sneasel, and Ribombee. Arctovish appreciates entry hazard support from Pokemon like Gigalith, Weezing, and Ferroseed, as the support helps whittle down Pokemon like Jellicent, Tangela, and Ferroseed. Teammates like Magneton, Archeops, and Mesprit can lure in defensive Pokemon like Audino, Gigalith, and Sandaconda and safely pivot into Arctovish using Volt Switch and U-turn.

Glastrier.overview: Glastrier's astronomical Attack stat along with a great offensive typing and useful coverage in Close Combat, Crunch, and High Horsepower gives it a niche as a potent wallbreaker. Additionally, great natural bulk even uninvested lets Glastrier take neutral hits reasonably well from a plethora of threats in the tier. However, what it has in offensive power, Glastrier lacks in defensive utility. Despite its great bulk, Glastrier's poor defensive typing gives it a weakness to Stealth Rock and leaves it vulnerable to foes like Charizard, Gallade, and Lycanroc. Glastrier's miserable Speed stat only exacerbates this issue, leaving it outsped by Pokemon like Weezing and Jellicent and makes it prone to being revenge killed by the likes of Gallade, Galarian Articuno, and Centiskorch. In addition to this, Glastrier struggles to make progress against Pokemon like Levitate Weezing, Quagsire, and Doublade, making its performance as a wallbreaker somewhat questionable against more defensively-oriented teams. Furthermore, it faces stiff competition as an Ice-type wallbreaker from Sneasel, which boasts better Speed, a more useful offensive typing that gives it access to STAB Knock Off, and a stronger Ice-type STAB attack in Triple Axel.

Swords Dance.description:
Close Combat provides useful coverage for Pokemon that can comfortably take Icicle Crash, like Gigalith, Ferroseed, Silvally-Steel, and Aggron. Glastrier's last slot has some variety. Crunch provides crucial coverage for Pokemon that resist Icicle Crash like Jellicent, Centiskorch, and Doublade. High Horsepower is an option that lets Glastrier hit Neutralizing Gas Weezing, Lanturn, and Doublade harder while also synergizing better with Close Combat. However, it provides less important coverage than Crunch, making it inferior much of the time.

Glastrier's defensive shortcomings due to its Ice typing and miserable Speed mean that support from pivots such as Ribombee, Wishiwashi, and Mesprit is essential for it. Grass-types like Eldegoss, Thwackey, and Whimsicott make for excellent partners, as they can break through Water-types like Quagsire and Lanturn that would otherwise inhibit Glastrier’s offensive potential. Eldegoss provides much-appreciated entry hazard removal in the case that Glastrier loses its item, and Whimsicott provides great utility in Sleep Powder and Knock Off to punish switch-ins like Centiskorch and Lanturn while also having a flexible offensive presence that allows it to assist versus Pokemon like Weezing and Quagsire. Thwackey provides useful Grassy Terrain support, which gives Glastrier better overall longevity. Charizard is another excellent offensive partner, as it can assist with breaking through Pokemon such as Weezing and Centiskorch while appreciating Glastrier's ability to break through Gigalith.
